and a map of the area considered for annexation;
      2.   The governing body shall determine if the area considered for
annexation is in minimum compliance with section
9-5-2 of this chapter. If the area is in minimum compliance, the town council
shall adopt a resolution to that effect and the procedure outlined in section
9-5-6 of this chapter shall then be followed. If the area is not in minimum
compliance, no further action shall be taken on the proposed annexation. (Ord.
2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-5-4: PRELIMINARY AND FINAL PLATS:
All annexations must be processed with a preliminary and final plat as
described in chapters 3 and 4 of this title. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-5-5: ANNEXATION REPORT:
The town shall prepare, review, and distribute an annexation report for each
annexation in accordance with Wyoming Statutes 15-1-402(c). (Ord. 2012-04, 7-
17-2012)
9-5-6: PUBLIC HEARINGS:
   A.   Time And Place Of Public Hearing; Notice:
      1.   As a part of a resolution finding minimum compliance of an
annexation petition, or as a part of a resolution for annexation proceedings
initiated by the town, the governing body shall establish a date, time, and
place when a public hearing will be held to determine if the proposed
annexation complies with section
9-5-2 of this chapter. The hearing shall be held not less than thirty (30) days
nor more than one hundred eighty (180) days after the effective date of the
resolution.
      2.   The town clerk shall give notice of the public hearing by publishing
a notice at least twice in a newspaper of general circulation in the territory
sought to be annexed, with the first notice given at least fifteen (15) days
prior to the date of the public hearing. Not less than twenty (20) business
days prior to the public hearing, the town shall send by certified mail to all
landowners and affected public utilities within the area of annexation, a
summary of the proposed annexation report and notice of the time, dates, and
location of the public hearing.
   B.   Annexation Ordinance; Objections: If, after the hearing, the governing
body finds that the conditions as required by section
9-5-2 of this chapter exist and that the required procedures have been met, it
shall annex the territory by ordinance.
   C.   Written Objections: If more than fifty percent (50%) of the landowners,
or if a landowner or landowners owning more than fifty percent (50%) of the
area to be annexed file written objections with the town clerk within twenty
(20) business days after the hearing under this section no further action may
be taken on any area within the proposed annexation within two (2) years.
   D.   Exception: If seventy five percent (75%) or more of the perimeter of
the area to be annexed is contiguous to the corporate limits of the town, the
provisions of subsection C of this section do not apply.
   E.   When Notice And Public Hearing Not Required: When the town is a sole
owner of any territory whether or not contiguous that it desires to annex, the
town council may, by ordinance, annex the territory to the town without notice
or public hearing as provided in this section. All ordinances annexing
territory without notice and public hearing shall contain a statement that the
territory is solely owned by the petitioning town. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-5-7: EFFECTIVE DATE OF ANNEXATION:
The annexation of any territory becomes effective upon the date provided in the
ordinance. However, for purposes of taxation, the annexation does not become
effective until January 1 next following the effective date of the ordinance,
unless an appeal is filed and perfected, in which case the effective date shall
be January 1 next following the court's final decision of the matter.
   A.   The ordinance adopted to approve annexation of any territory shall be
filed at the county clerk's office. Upon filing, the original ordinance shall
be filed in the ordinance book, and a copy will be filed with the annexation
documents. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-5-8: EXTENSION OF LAWS AND REGULATIONS TO ANNEXED AREA:
The territory and inhabitants of any annexed area shall be subject to all the
laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the town, and shall be entitled to
all the rights, privileges, and franchise services afforded the inhabitants
thereof including fire protection, sanitary facilities, and utility service. In
the event that the inhabitants of the town are furnished any utility service by
the town or under franchise, the annexed area shall receive the same service.
(Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
CHAPTER 6
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
9-6-1: Minimum Standards
9-6-2: Conformity To Master Plan
9-6-3: General Engineering Principles For Streets And Utilities
9-6-4: Streets And Roadways
9-6-5: Water And Sewer
9-6-6: Water Facilities
9-6-7: Sanitary Sewer Collection Facilities
9-6-8: Storm Sewer Facilities
9-6-9: Public Sites And Open Spaces
9-6-1: MINIMUM STANDARDS:
The design standards set out in this chapter shall be held to be the minimum
design standards.
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of these standards is to consolidate the rules,
regulations, and guidelines covering the overall design for the development
(design and construction) of infrastructure in the town of Bar Nunn, including
roads, traffic, open spaces, storm sewer, drainage, and other utilities. The
complexity and growth of our systems necessitates standardizing design and
construction practices that will provide a consolidated guideline to facilitate
proper maintenance and operation of the systems and town.
It is not the intention of this chapter to limit or hinder new or innovative
ideas or procedures. We recognize there will be situations in which deviations
from this chapter may benefit the town. The town will consider changes and
alterations on an individual situation basis. Changes and alterations may be
granted provided the design reflects solid, good engineering practices and does
not violate county, state, or federal codes and regulations or town standards.
If a conflict exists, the more stringent standard shall apply.
The objective of these standards is to provide long range and consistent
guidelines to follow and provide a standardization of materials and reduce
maintenance costs to maintain the town's interest.
   B.   Materials And Workmanship: All materials, workmanship, and construction
practices shall conform to these standards and other applicable codes and
regulations. If the developer requests in writing the use of a material or
construction method that is not considered standard practice, the developer
must obtain written approval from the town prior to implementation.
   C.   Accuracy And Adequacy Of Plans: All plans and documents stipulating
construction requirements, soils reports, water and sewer studies, drainage
studies, traffic studies, erosion control plans, and similar documents shall be
stamped by a registered professional engineer licensed to practice in the state
of Wyoming, in accordance with Wyoming Statutes 33-29-136 through 33-29-139.
   D.   Construction And Infrastructure Standards: If not specifically covered
by these standards, the city of Casper "Standard Specifications For Public
Works Construction And Infrastructure Improvements" (latest edition) shall
apply. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-6-2: CONFORMITY TO MASTER PLAN:
The proposed subdivision or property or change shall substantially conform to
any adopted master plan, growth plan, or the adopted guide for growth for the
town. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-6-3: GENERAL ENGINEERING PRINCIPLES FOR STREETS AND UTILITIES:
   A.   Block Length: Residential block lengths shall not exceed one thousand
three hundred twenty feet (1,320') except that a greater length may be
permitted when justified by topography or other conditions as approved by the
town.
   B.   Lots:
      1.   Residential lots, and other lots where applicable, should make every
effort to be arranged to afford the best possible view, privacy, orientation
for solar energy and air, safety, and utilization of natural features. Lot
arrangements should achieve local character and good appearance.
      2.   The minimum area for all lots shall not be less than that required
by the zoning ordinance for the specific district.
      3.   All lots shall have direct access to a dedicated street.
      4.   Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles to straight
street lines or radial to curved street lines.
      5.   All lots deemed by the town to be subject to flooding by the flood
insurance study prepared by the federal emergency management agency dated July
2004, or any updates to the study, shall neither be developed for residential
occupancy or for such other uses as may endanger health, life or property, or
aggravate the flood hazard, unless in compliance with the requirements of FEMA.
      6.   All lots abutting arterial streets shall have a six foot (6') high
solid fence or wall constructed by the developer in the property lines abutting
the right of way, unless this requirement is waived by the town council during
the plat or replat review process.
      7.   The minimum landscaping for all lots shall not be less than that
required by the zoning ordinance for the specific district.
   C.   Street Requirements Generally: The arrangement, character, extent,
width, grade, and location of streets shall substantially conform to the
official street map, the long range transportation plan and the comprehensive
conceptual land use plan adopted guide for growth related to existing and
planned streets, topography, to public convenience and safety.
   D.   Continuation Of Existing Streets: Streets or utility rights of way in
new subdivisions shall make provision for the continuation and connectivity of
existing streets and rights of way in adjoining areas.
   E.   Street Signs: Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the developer
shall agree to make the signs per the town's specifications and are subject to
approval by the town. Signs will be installed by the developer at no cost to
the town. Signs shall meet WYDOT and MUTCD standards.
   F.   Easements For Drainage And Utilities:
      1.   Easements with a right of way width of fifteen feet (15') shall be
provided on each front lot line and along certain side lot lines and rear lot
lines where necessary for utilities or drainage. During initial construction of
utilities, there shall be a fifteen foot (15') temporary utility easement
adjacent to and on both sides of all permanent easements. These temporary
easements shall remain in effect until two (2) years after town's acceptance of
project.
      2.   Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, natural drainage
channel or stream, there shall be provided a drainage easement of sufficient
width for surface or subsurface drainage, as approved by the engineer and town.
This drainage easement for surface or subsurface drainage should conform
substantially with the existing lines of the watercourse and master plans. A
drainage study shall be submitted and approved by the town engineer.
      3.   All distribution facilities providing utility services to a proposed
subdivision, including, but not limited to, water, sewer, natural gas, electric
power, telephone or telegraph, and cable television, shall be buried within the
easements or rights of way provided on the plat, excepting those facilities, as
approved by the town council to be placed aboveground in the right of way.
Plans and designs for the burial of such utility services shall be submitted to
and receive the approval of the town engineer, prior to their installation.
      4.   In residential areas, all gas meters shall be located behind the
front building line adjacent to the side lot line, except where an alley is
available, in which case all dry utilities should be located in the alley. No
aboveground utility service facilities (gas, telephone, power, or cable
television) shall be located in the front yard without the approval of the town
engineer.
      5.   The minimum easement width for storm sewers shall be the greater of
twenty feet (20'), or eighteen feet (18') plus the diameter of the largest
pipe, whichever is greater. Easements containing storm sewer, sanitary sewer
and/or water lines must have a minimum width that is adequate to provide for a
ten foot (10') separation between pipelines and allow ten feet (10') from the
centerline of the outside pipes to the easement boundary. OSHA standards may
apply to above.
   G.   Townhouse And Planned Unit Development (PUD) Developments:
      1.   For developments of twenty (20) residential units or less, the town
will accept dedicated public roadways in planned unit developments (PUD) or
cluster type (townhouse) developments, less than minimum standards, per
approval by the town engineer, planning and zoning, and town council. For
developments with over twenty (20) residential units or for commercial uses,
public street right of way and streets shall be developed to regular town
standards to provide adequate pedestrian access and facilities. If the town is
to maintain the infrastructure, it shall meet the town standards.
      2.   If individual lots are to be sold, planned unit developments or
cluster type housing shall be designed and platted in such a manner that each
platted lot will abut and have access to a dedicated public street, or have
adequate access and utility easement providing for ingress, egress and
necessary municipal services, as well as meet the minimum criteria set forth in
this section.
      3.   Private drives will be permitted in a PUD, provided that the
following conditions are met:
         a.   No cul-de-sac shall exceed six hundred feet (600') in length.
         b.   No private drive shall be aligned to connect to a public
dedicated street in such a manner that will encourage the private drive to be
utilized as a public street.
      4.   The town shall have no responsibility for operation and maintenance
of water and sewer mains nor private streets located within PUD or cluster type
developments, unless some level of responsibility is established through a
subdivision agreement. All water agreements shall be with the Wardwell water
district; Wardwell water district is the governing water entity.
      5.   Separate sewer service lines will be required for each unit in a PUD
or cluster type development if a homeowners' association exists within the
development that is responsible for operation and maintenance of all sewer
service lines to a main located in a public street.
      6.   All water and sewer service lines serving individual units,
regardless of operation and maintenance responsibilities, must be located in
dedicated utility easements.
      7.   Connection charge fees will be assessed in a similar manner for both
townhouses and condominiums. Connection charge fees will be assessed as
determined by the town of Bar Nunn and Wardwell water district.
      8.   If lots are to be sold individually in a PUD or other zoning
district as townhouses, each lot must be platted in accordance with town
requirements.
      9.   Wardwell water district approval of all water connections and
services is required. Wardwell water district is the owner of the water system.
   H.   Intersections: Intersections shall also meet the ADA requirement in
subsection K12 of this section as well as other federal and state requirements
at a minimum.
      1.   A maximum of four (4) approaches is allowed at any intersection.
      2.   Colored concrete crosswalks shall be installed at all intersections,
when requested by the town.
      3.   ADA ramps shall be provided at all corners of all intersections.
         a.   New and retrofit collector, arterial, and residential streets
with sidewalks: All new arterial streets shall have colored ADA ramps. The ramp
color shall be a red or brick red color as approved of by the town. A
detectable warning mat with truncated domes shall be installed on top of the
colored ADA ramps. The location of the mat shall be in accordance with federal
regulations and the installation shall meet the manufacturer's recommendations.
         b.   A separate ADA ramp shall be provided for each street crossing,
except single corner ramps will be allowed under special circumstances when
approved by the town engineer.
   I.   Frontage Roads Near Arterials: Where a subdivision abuts an existing or
proposed arterial street, the town may require a frontage road to protect
residential properties and separate through and local traffic.
   J.   Sidewalks, Curbs And Gutters, Curbwalks:
      1.   General Requirements: All street sections within the town shall
include curb and gutter, curb and gutter with sidewalk or curbwalk unless
determined by the town council. At minimum, curb and gutter is required on all
streets.
         a.   Residential Areas: Curb and gutter with sidewalk or curbwalk
shall be required on both sides of local and collector streets except as
otherwise determined by the town.
         b.   Commercial Areas: Curb and gutter with sidewalk or curbwalk shall
be required on both sides of the street in all commercial areas except when the
requirement is waived by the town.
         c.   Industrial Areas: Curb and gutter is required on both sides of
streets. Sidewalks are required on at least one side of the street except as
determined by the town.
   K.   Infrastructure Design:
      1.   Investigations: All reports shall be sealed and signed by the
appropriate Wyoming licensed person.
         a.   Geotechnical Requirements: A geotechnical investigation of the
project site shall be provided unless determined otherwise by the town.
Borings, sampling, and testing shall be performed in accordance with the
applicable ASTM standards. Tests performed shall include, but not be limited
to, CBR, unconfined compressive strength, and shearing strength.
         b.   Soil: Recommendations for suitability of the soil conditions for
the proposed construction, including recommendations on trench excavations and
backfill, shall be provided based on the information obtained from the soil
borings and sampling.
            (1)   Underground utility construction: At a minimum, perform one
test boring per residential block.
            (2)   Roadway construction: Perform soil sampling as necessary for
pavement design. Refer to subsection 9-6-4R2d of this chapter.
            (3)   Sampling tests and/or procedures and the associated report
shall address the following items:
   (A) Engineering properties, including moisture content, Atterburg limits,
sieve analyses, and standard resistance as determined by blow counts per foot.
   (B) Soil profile logs covering pavement thickness and soil types encountered
to the depth of the borings.
   (C) Groundwater depth determination, if encountered.
   (D) Include soil boring locations on the project design drawings.
   (E) Classification of subgrade materials under the unified soil
classification (USC) system.
   (F) Soil samples from each test boring shall be screened for volatile
organic compounds (VOC) using a photoionization detector (PID). The PID shall
be performed on samples from the boring exhibiting the highest potential for
VOC contamination. In the event PID testing and/or visual observations of soil
boring material indicates the presence of contamination, after discussion with
town staff, soil samples shall be screened for gasoline and diesel range
organic compounds using DRO/GRO testing procedures to further define the soil
contamination.
      2.   Underground Facilities: See subsection F, "Easements For Drainage
And Utilities", of this section.
         a.   Comply with Wyoming state statutes title 37 for requirements
regarding underground facilities. In particular, comply with "Any person
requiring excavation or design for excavation shall obtain information from
persons with underground facilities, as to the nature, location, and depth if
known, of underground facilities. If the information is not available, the
person requiring excavation shall determine at their expense the nature and
location of the underground facilities. The person requiring excavation shall
make the information and location a part of the plan by which the excavators
operate".
         b.   Private utility companies shall be contacted (i.e., telephone,
power, cable television, gas, etc.) to obtain location of their utilities on
the project and to coordinate any required adjustments. The one call locate
centers shall also be called in advance.
         c.   Site plans shall include all existing utilities; utilities to be
removed, abandoned, or relocated; and all proposed utilities. Utilities
includes water, sewer, gas, phone, cable television, electric power, etc., that
may exist or be desired. All potential conflicts shall be addressed.
      3.   Traffic Study: A traffic study shall be required for any development
that will produce seventy five (75) or more vehicle trips per peak hour. The
town engineer may arrange for a traffic study to be prepared. The cost of the
study will be borne by the developer. The traffic study shall include the
requirements as outlined in chapter 3, "Preliminary Plats", of this title.
      4.   Stormwater Management:
         a.   All site and subdivision plans shall include information on
proposed drainage features, including initial and final contours, paved area,
landscaped area, building area, location of roof drain outlets, gutters,
swales, catch basins, storm drain piping, etc.
         b.   When required by the town engineer for sites under ten thousand
(10,000) square feet, and for all sites over ten thousand (10,000) square feet,
a drainage study prepared in accordance with the town's master plans, following
the city of Casper "Storm Water Management Design Manual" by a professional
engineer registered in the state of Wyoming shall be prepared. All design
criteria and assumptions shall follow the policies set forth in the design
manual.
      5.   Sanitary Sewer System Study: Prepare a sanitary sewer system study
for the proposed project and the existing system to the extent required by the
town and DEQ. Modeling of the system shall be performed if requested.
      6.   Survey Requirements:
         a.   General: Provide all necessary surveying required for the
proposed work. All engineering surveys required for the planning, design, and
construction of infrastructure and appurtenances, including detailed layout and
staking for installation, shall be the responsibility of the person, firm, or
corporation requesting or receiving the approval to construct. Such surveys
shall be made or performed by a professional engineer or land surveyor licensed
to practice in the state of Wyoming.
         b.   Datum: All elevations shown on plans or drawings, or referred to
in the specifications, shall be referred to the elevation above mean sea level
as established by the national geodetic survey. The datum used shall not be an
assumed elevation, or arbitrary designation of elevations not corresponding to
correct datum.
         c.   GIS: Survey data shall be compatible with the town of Bar Nunn
and the city of Casper geographic information systems using state plane
coordinates (NAD 83/86 East Central).
      7.   Project Signage: At the discretion and approval of town council,
projects being financed with any optional sales tax funding may have
advertising signs installed at prominent locations. This needs to be
accomplished prior to the first week of construction. Signs will be furnished
by the town to the contractor. Contractor shall furnish posts, hardware, and
installation. Consultant shall include this information in the bidding
documents.
      8.   Public Service Announcements: Contractor shall provide for public
service announcements for the infrastructure improvements and other projects
that are anticipated to inconvenience the public in any way for a time period
longer than one day. The extent and content of public service announcements
will vary with the project.
      9.   Aesthetics:
         a.   Electrical Services:
            (1)   Consideration shall be given to the aesthetic elements of
construction projects including electrical service equipment. The replacement
of such items shall be coordinated with town staff and the electric company.
Specific concerns are:
   (A) No meter cans shall be placed on poles;
   (B) Meter placement shall be at least three feet (3') from the pole;
   (C) Electric company access to the meter shall be of primary importance;
   (D) The town must closely coordinate the work of electrical subcontractors
for nonelectrical utility construction.
            (2)   Prior to construction, such details as electrical drop views
and equipment locations shall be submitted to the town for approval.
            (3)   Colored concrete shall be used for crosswalk paving, ADA
ramps, and other features as directed by the town on a case by case basis.
            (4)   Brick pavers may be used at various locations at the
direction of the town. The brick specifications shall include the following:
               (A) Brick shall be free of cracks or other imperfections
detracting from the appearance of a designated sample when viewed from a
distance of fifteen feet (15'). Parts of the brick that will be exposed in
place shall be free of chips.
               (B) Size shall be a standard of 7.62 inches long, 3.81 inches
wide, and 2.25 inches deep.
               (C) Due to the variation of colors produced during
manufacturing, samples of the batch(es) of brick proposed for use shall be
submitted for approval, prior to installation. Samples consisting of full size
units (minimum number of 6) for each color and texture showing full range of
variations expected in these characteristics shall be submitted to the town for
approval.
               (D) If other manufacturers' products are approved as equal, the
contractor shall be responsible to submit and to calculate any and all
modifications to installation details, dimensions of areas to receive brick and
other information as may be requested by the town or as may be required due to
variations in brick size or other factors.
               (E) Brick materials shall be solid brick pavers, complying with
ASTM C902, weather class, SX, traffic type 1, application PX with an average
absorption rate of four percent (4%), abrasion index of type 1, a maximum
saturation coefficient of 0.85, and a modulus rupture of 1.45 ksi. Approved
brick manufacturer Boral Brick, "bourbon" or approved equal.
            (5)   Alternatives may be approved at the discretion of the town.
      10.   Construction Traffic Control: Reference subsection K13,
"Construction Documents", of this section.
      11.   Oversizing: Construction of streets of greater width, or sewer
piping in excess of the size required for the development or in excess of the
minimum required size may be required. Consult the applicable town master plans
or studies and with the town engineer to identify oversizing requirements. At
the town council's discretion, the town may reimburse the developer/contractor
for the cost in excess of that required for the development. Water pipe sizing
is at the discretion of Wardwell water and the town of Bar Nunn.
      12.   ADA Requirements: All new infrastructure projects shall incorporate
Americans with disabilities act features in accordance with federal
requirements and the requirements of the Bar Nunn regulations and codes. Also,
reference subsection H, "Intersections", of this section.
      13.   Construction Documents:
         a.   General: Construction documents shall consist of drawings
representative of the work to be performed, general and special provisions, and
technical specifications. The following shall be required unless otherwise
approved in advance by the town.
         b.   Construction Drawings:
            (1)   Construction drawings shall contain sufficient detail and
information to determine construction costs and to construct the improvements.
Standard drawing sheet shall be twenty four inches by thirty six inches (24" x
36"), eleven inches by seventeen inches (11" x 17"), or as approved by the
town. All information on the drawings shall be legible.
            (2)   Plan and profile sheets shall have a horizontal scale smaller
than one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50'), and an appropriate vertical scale.
Drawings shall accurately represent the extent of infrastructure improvements
and appurtenances (e.g., service lines and manholes) and utility conflict
locations.
            (3)   Plan information shall include street alignment; parcel
lines; right of way; proposed sidewalks, street centerline; curb and gutter or
curbwalk; demolition and salvage; proposed alignments of water lines and sewer
lines (storm sewer and sanitary sewer); existing underground and overhead
utilities; length and grade of pipes; pipe material and size; location of
manholes, valves, and fire hydrants; pavement rehabilitation; surfacing and
landscaping; and any other work relevant to the project.
            (4)   Profile information shall include estimated (actual if known)
depths of existing underground utilities and alignments of proposed utilities.
Proposed underground utilities shall include grades, stationing, and lengths,
sizes, classifications, type, and ratings.
            (5)   In addition, typical sections, summaries, and details shall
be included as necessary.
            (6)   Preliminary, final, and record drawings shall be in computer
aided drafting format. Digital format shall be compatible with the town's CAD
and GIS system.
            (7)   Three (3) copies of the "draft" construction drawings and
project manuals shall be submitted to town office staff for review.
            (8)   A traffic control plan in construction drawings, at an
appropriate scale shall be included. The plan shall depict phased construction
of the project to minimize inconvenience to local traffic, residents, and
homeowners as necessary.
For projects where traffic control is anticipated to be necessary during
construction, consultant shall include specifications and provision for payment
for traffic control in the bidding/construction documents. Contractors must
submit traffic control plans to the town engineer and town clerk prior to start
of work. All traffic control shall comply with the "Manual On Uniform Traffic
Control Devices", latest edition (MUTCD).
         c.   Project Manual:
            (1)   Bidding And Contract Documents:
               (A) Engineer's joint contract documents committee (EJCDC)
standard forms for bidding documents, agreement, bonds, etc., shall be used.
Consultant shall recommend project specific modifications for preparation by
the town.
               (B) Consultant shall provide bid schedules and measurement and
payment requirements appropriate for the project.
               (C) Consultant shall provide general provisions and special
provisions sections specific for the project. The town's format or consultant's
format may be used.
            (2)   Specifications:
               (A) Specifications covering the materials and requirements of
construction shall be submitted with the plans when presented for approval.
City of Casper standard specifications will be used supplemented by special
provisions or CSI format technical specifications, or Bar Nunn approved equal,
as appropriate to the particular project.
               (B) Special time lines, phasing requirement and dates for
partial substantial completion that will trigger liquidated damages shall be
clearly explained in the special provisions and referenced in the agreement.
Reference subsection K13k of this section for requirements.
            (3)   Town Insurance: Project manual must include current town
insurance requirements.
            (4)   Warranty: See subsection K13k of this section for warranty
requirements.
         d.   Construction:
            (1)   Construction Observation:
               (A) All construction of infrastructure and appurtenances covered
within the scope of these standards shall be observed for compliance with the
standards, and for conformance with the approved plans and specifications.
               (B) If the work is performed by a developer's contractor, the
developer's engineer shall provide a competent resident project representative
(RPR) for the work, and all required inspection and testing shall be
coordinated through said RPR. Materials installed, or work performed not in
compliance with the approved plans and specifications, shall be removed,
replaced, or made acceptable, before the construction will be accepted by the
town of Bar Nunn. The developer and the developer's engineer shall certify in
writing, that all work has been completed in compliance with its approved plans
and specifications, before acceptance and start of the warranty period.
               (C) Consultant's RPR shall at all times maintain a copy of the
project specifications and a redline set of as built record drawings on site
available for reference.
               (D) RPR shall maintain a daily log of construction activities,
weather conditions, personnel, and equipment used on the project. Any out of
scope emergency work shall be monitored and logged including the equipment used
and its source, personnel required of the work, personnel on site and materials
used. A copy of the log shall be on site and available for reference at all
times.
               (E) At any time during the project, the town at its discretion
may require full time on site inspection.
         e.   Project Coordination:
            (1)   Prior to construction, a preconstruction conference shall be
organized and conducted by the engineer or developer. The contractor,
representatives of all affected utilities, town staff, and any affected party
shall be invited.
            (2)   Developer or engineer shall be responsible for coordination
with the Wyoming department of environmental quality (DEQ) as well as with all
affected business owners, regulatory entities, utility companies, community
services, residents, and property owners within the project areas. This shall
include timely notification of construction activities as necessary and the
procurement of all necessary certifications from the appropriate agency or
agencies.
            (3)   Each time traffic control setups are revised, the revisions
shall be communicated to the town's office.
            (4)   Contractor or developer shall notify all emergency services
and community services of any and all descriptions and changes.
         f.   Construction Survey And Control:
            (1)   Consultant shall show control points, bench marks, etc., on
the drawings and provide the related pins, staking, etc., in the field, as
necessary to construct the project.
            (2)   Consultant shall periodically verify the contractor's survey
work to ensure compliance with project requirements.
            (3)   State licensure requirements shall be adhered to for
construction survey and control.
         g.   Testing:
            (1)   Materials and other testing shall be provided by a firm
specializing in that work and approved by the town of Bar Nunn. Testing shall
be paid for by the contractor, unless stated differently in agreements with the
town. Compliance with city of Casper standard specifications for types and
frequency for testing shall be required. All required testing shall be
performed and documented for review by town staff. Acceptance of the work will
be based on satisfactory results of all required testing.
         h.   Record Documents:
            (1)   Consultant shall provide to the town of Bar Nunn record
drawings showing those changes made during the construction process, based on
the consultant's observation, marked up prints, drawings, and other data
furnished by the contractor.
            (2)   Within thirty (30) days of substantial completion of
construction, developer or engineer shall submit one hard copy and one copy in
digital format. The hard copy shall be on twenty four inch by thirty six inch
(24" x 36") or eleven inch by seventeen inch (11" x 17") reproducible four (4)
mil mylar. The digital copy shall be in AutoCAD format, and on properly labeled
CDs.
            (3)   A GPS digital file compatible with the town's and the city of
Casper's GIS showing all new improvements shall be provided with the record
documents and include coordinates for all new surface features such as: trees,
pedestrian lighting, traffic signals, signs, water valves, meter pits,
hydrants, sanitary sewer, and storm sewer utilities. State plane coordinates
(NAD 83/86 East Central) for inclusion in the GIS mapping shall be utilized.
The consultant shall work with the town's staff and city of Casper's staff to
ensure the data collected can be downloaded to the GIS. Accuracy requirements
are ±1.25 feet horizontal.
         i.   Stormwater Regulations: See this subsection K and stormwater
regulations, erosion control plans and bonds; for stormwater and erosion
requirements.
         j.   Acceptance:
            (1)   Acceptance of the work shall be based on compliance with the
drawings, specifications, and quality.
         k.   Warranty: Special warranty requirements shall be included in the
construction documents as appropriate. Describe requirements for start of
warranty, duration of warranty and requirements for acceptance by the town
where applicable.
            (1)   Standard Warranty: Standard warranty for town of Bar Nunn
projects is a one year period beginning with the date of the town's final
acceptance.
            (2)   Subdivision Warranty: Subdivision warranty is required by the
subdivision agreement and shall begin after all punch list items have been
completed unless otherwise agreed to.
            (3)   Warranty Against Defects: Owners (developers), heirs,
successors in interest, and assigns covered by the subdivision agreement or
water and sewer (sanitary and storm) contract, shall warrant or guarantee the
construction of public improvements against defects in workmanship or
materials, including settlement of backfill. The owners, etc., shall make all
needed repairs arising out of such defective workmanship or materials, or both,
which in the judgment of the town staff shall become necessary during such
period.
         l.   Schools; Traffic Circulation:
            (1)   School bus drop off locations shall be located off the street
right of way. Drop off zones for buses shall not be within street rights of
way. Parent parking and drop off zones shall be located in designated parking
and driving zones off the street right of way. Parent parking and school bus
drop off locations at school facilities shall not conflict with the traffic
patterns of each other. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-6-4: STREETS AND ROADWAYS:
All designs shall be in accordance with this section. For additional design
criteria, the following policies and guidelines shall be followed: "A Policy On
Geometric Design Of Highways And Streets" published by AASHTO, "Guidelines For
Residential Subdivision Street Design", "Neighborhood Street Design
Guidelines", and "Guidelines For Urban Major Streets" all published by the
Institute Of Transportation Engineers. All engineering criteria listed in this
section shall take precedent over the above referenced manuals, unless
otherwise approved by the town. The arrangement, character, extent, width,
grade, and location of streets and roadways shall conform to the official
street map and adopted guide for growth related to existing and planned
streets, topography, to public convenience and safety, and to the use of lands
served by such streets.
   A.   Streets Or Utility Rights Of Way In New Subdivisions: Streets or
utility rights of way in new subdivisions shall make provision for the
continuation of existing streets in adjoining areas.
   B.   Dedication: Dedication of half streets, except for collector streets or
arterial streets as shown on the master plan, adopted guides for growth and
planning, plans, and other town documents is prohibited, unless such
requirement shall be waived by the town council.
   C.   Alignment: When streets are in alignment with existing streets, the new
streets shall be named according to the streets with which they correspond.
Streets which do not fit into the established street naming pattern shall be
named in a manner which will not duplicate or be confused with existing street
names. Street names for a subdivision shall be related groups of things or
people indigenous to the town and state; for example, city or state trees,
flowers, animals, fish, birds, pioneers, statesmen, trails, creeks, brands,
rocks, minerals, Indian tribes, warriors, chiefs or Indian names, mountains,
grasses, etc.
   D.   Physical Address: Physical address numbers shall be assigned after the
plat is recorded in accordance with the physical address numbering system now
in effect in the town. Physical address numbers shall not be shown on the
subdivision plat.
   E.   Street Jogs With Centerline Offsets: Street jogs with centerline
offsets of less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') are prohibited unless
approved by the town council.
   F.   Dead End Streets, Cul-De-Sacs, And Driveways: Dead end streets or cul-
de-sacs shall not be longer than six hundred feet (600') and shall be provided
at the closed end with a turnaround having a right of way radius of sixty feet
(60'). Dead end streets and cul-de-sacs shall be paved with hard surfacing,
such as asphalt paving and shall have sidewalk and curb and gutter to match to
the connecting streets.
If a dead end street is of a temporary nature and is one lot length or more, a
similar temporary turnaround easement having a right of way radius of sixty
feet (60') shall be provided until provisions have been made for the extension
of the street into adjoining properties. The temporary turnaround easement may
be relinquished after the permanent right of way and street are established. A
temporary dead end street may be surfaced with a minimum of four inches (4")
asphalt paving or other approved hard surfacing.
Driveways and private accesses shall not be aligned with public roads or
dedicated rights of way in such a manner that will encourage them to be used as
public streets.
   G.   Subdivision Abutting Existing Streets: Where a subdivision abuts an
existing arterial or major street, the town may require marginal access streets
or other treatment to protect residential properties and separate through and
local traffic.
   H.   Street Width: Street width shall not be less than as follows:
Street Type Minimum            Minimum
            Right Of Way Width Paving Width
Street Type                    Minimum            Minimum
                               Right Of Way Width Paving Width
Freeway                        200 – 300 ft.    48 ft. variable
Arterial                       120 ft.            Variable
Arterial (single roadway)      80 ft.             67 ft.
Collector                      64 ft.             48 ft.
Residential                    52 ft.             36 ft.
Cul-de-sac                     65 ft. radius      55 ft. radius (no sidewalk)
Marginal access                50 ft.             26 ft.
Alley - residential            20 ft.             20 ft.
Alley - other than residential 24 ft.             24 ft.
 
   I.   Connecting Street Lines And Deflection: When connecting street lines
deflect from each other at any one point more than fifteen degrees (15°) they
shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to ensure a sight distance
of not less than one hundred fifty feet (150') for collector streets, and/or
such greater radii as the town shall determine for arterial streets. The site
triangle is defined as the distance twenty five feet by twenty five feet (25' x
25') as measured along the property line.
   J.   Tangents And Reverse Curves: A tangent at least one hundred feet (100')
long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector
streets.
   K.   Grades: All grades shall be more than one-half of one percent (0.5%)
and less than seven percent (7%) for freeway, arterial and collector streets,
and less than eight percent (8%) for all other streets. Vertical curves shall
be provided at all breaks in street grades when the algebraic difference
between the grades is greater than one. The length of such vertical curves
shall be such as to provide a sight distance of not less than one hundred fifty
feet (150').
   L.   Freeway, Arterial, And Collector Street Grades: Freeway, arterial, and
collector streets shall substantially be leveled to a grade of less than four
percent (4%) for a distance of at least one hundred feet (100') approaching
intersections.
All streets shall be leveled to a grade of less than two percent (2%) for a
distance of at least sixty feet (60') approaching intersections. If this cannot
be maintained, then the streets shall be leveled for a grade of less than four
percent (4%) for a distance of at least one hundred feet (100') approaching
intersections.
   M.   Cross Slope: The cross slope on all paved streets, including
intersections, shall be three percent (3%) or less, shall have a center crown,
shall not have a quarter crown, and shall not have a vertical difference of
more than four tenths of one foot (0.4') from flow line to flow line unless
previously approved by the town engineer. The desired cross slope shall be two
percent (2%).
   N.   Borders: Where a subdivision borders a railroad right of way, the town
may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right
of way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land.
Such distances shall also be determined with due regard of approach grades and
future grade separation.
   O.   Contours: In general, streets shall be contoured along hills or slight
angles to hills to preserve the character of the terrain.
   P.   Soil Classifications: For a thorough description and evaluation of
these classifications, please refer to subsection R3, "Construction Standards",
of this section.
   Q.   Vertical Curve Design Guidelines: Stopping sight distances and
intersection layout:
      1.   Vertical curves shall be determined by the following formula:
L = KA
 
Where L = Length of vertical curve in feet
      K = Design constant
      A = Algebraic difference in grades (%)
 
Values for K shall be in accordance with a "Policy On Geometric Design Of Urban
Highways And Arterial Streets", fourth edition, AASHTO, 2001.
Design values, based on minimum stopping sight distance are as follows:
      2.   Crest vertical curves:
 
Design speed = 30 mph  K = 30 or   Lc = 190 ft. (min.)
Design speed = 40 mph  K = 70 or   Lc = 320 ft. (min.)
Design speed = 50 mph  K = 110 or  Lc = 450 ft. (min.)
 
Where: Lc = The minimum curve to be used.
      3.   Sag vertical curves:
 
Design speed = 30 mph  K = 40 or   Lc = 180 ft. (min.)
Design speed = 40 mph  K = 70 or   Lc = 205 ft. (min.)
Design speed = 50 mph  K = 110 or  Lc = 450 ft. (min.)
 
Where: Lc = The minimum curve to be used.
A table listing sight distances for all vertical curves shall be included on
drawings.
      4.   Streets shall substantially intersect at right angles. Local streets
shall have a clear site distance of ninety feet (90') measured along the
centerline of the curb lane of each approach. The town may require greater
sight distances at intersections of arterial and collector streets. A table
listing sight distances for arterial and collector street intersections shall
be included on drawings.
   R.   Pavement Design:
      1.   Design Methods: All pavement sections shall be designed according to
the AASHTO manual "Guide For The Design Of Pavement Structures", 1993 edition
or approved equal. Alternative design methods may be used with written
permission of the town engineer, provided the minimum requirements of this
section are met.
      2.   Design Criteria:
         a.   Residential Street And Alley Sections (Minimum Conditions):
            (1)   Traffic volumes: Six (6) ADT.
            (2)   Equivalent axle loads: Five (5) per day.
            (3)   Reliability: Ninety five percent (95%).
            (4)   Terminal serviceability index: 2.0.
            (5)   Analysis period: Twenty (20) years.
            (6)   Standards deviation: 0.44.
         b.   Collector And Arterial Street Sections: Pavement section design
of collector and arterial streets shall be designed using values supplied by
the town, or as determined by the traffic study for traffic volumes and
equivalent axle load.
         c.   Structural Layer Coefficients (Maximum): Structural layer
coefficient values for all streets shall meet the following:
            (1)   Pit run base: 0.10.
            (2)   Asphaltic concrete (AC) surface course: 0.40 (stability =
2,000 pounds).
            (3)   Asphaltic concrete (AC) binder course: 0.25.
            (4)   Grading W base: 0.11.
            (5)   Portland cement concrete (PCC): 0.40.
            (6)   Cement treated base (CTB): 0.20.
            (7)   Drainage coefficient: 1.00.
         d.   Minimum Pavement Section: The minimum pavement section for
residential, collector, and arterial streets shall be as follows or at the
discretion of the town engineer:
 
Street Classification Pavement Section
Residential streets   2" AC surface course over 2" AC binder course over 6"
                      grading W base
                      2" AC surface course over 2" AC binder course over 6"
Alleys                grading W base or 2" of 3/4" crushed gravel over 6"
                      grading W base
Collector streets     3" AC surface course over 3" AC binder course over 8"
                      grading W base
Arterial streets      3" AC surface course over 3" AC binder course over 8"
                      grading W base
 
         e.   Asphaltic Concrete (AC) Or Hot Mix Asphalt (HMA) Design: Job mix
designs for AC used on all streets shall incorporate the use of "performance
graded" (PG) asphaltic binder. The PG grade of binder shall be in accordance
with the city of Casper "Standard Specification For Public Works Construction
And Infrastructure Improvements" or as directed by the town. Minimum high
temperature designation shall be sixty four (64) and maximum low temperature
designation shall be minus twenty two (-22).
         f.   Written Documentation Required: Written documentation of pavement
designs and mix designs for both HMA and PCC shall be provided to the town. The
town shall provide information for values not provided in this standard.
         g.   Alternative Methods: Alternative pavement design methods may be
used with written permission from the town. Such method shall meet the minimum
requirements specified in this section.
         h.   Licensed Engineer: The road pavement structural section must be
designed by a licensed civil engineer registered in the state of Wyoming. The
design shall be submitted to the town and include supporting calculations,
assumptions, test results as necessary, soil strength data and anticipated
traffic loading for twenty (20) year design life. All roads shall be designed
for a twenty (20) year life unless prior approval to use another design life is
obtained. This data may be submitted in the form of a geotechnical and pavement
study/report. The study/report must be sealed and signed by the licensed
engineer.
      3.   Construction Standards: All construction standards shall meet the
city of Casper "Standard Specifications For Public Works Construction And
Infrastructure Improvements". If the city of Casper "Standard Specifications
For Public Works Construction And Infrastructure Improvements" are not
applicable, then the state of Wyoming department of transportation "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" shall apply. The information
specifically provided for by the town of Bar Nunn and as specifically written
herein shall supersede the city of Casper "Standard Specifications For Public
Works Construction And Infrastructure Improvements"; state of Wyoming
department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction"; and state of Wyoming DOT standards. When conflicts arise, the
most stringent shall apply.
Areas to support streets are divided into three (3) classifications depending
upon subgrade support characteristics; they are:
Fair to good subgrade,
Poor subgrade, and
Unacceptable subgrade.
The following is a description of each:
         a.   Fair To Good Subgrade: A fair to good subgrade are those with
soils classified in accordance with the AASHTO M-147-73 classification of A-
1 and A-5(0) to A-5(3). The area must have good drainage and the soil must not
exhibit expansive properties.
Minimum structural section components thicknesses for collector streets located
on this type of subgrade shall consist of four inches (4") of asphalt concrete
surface course over six inches (6") of aggregate base material over twelve
inches (12") of modified subgrade/prepared subbase. Minimum component
thicknesses for all other streets located on this type of subgrade shall
consist of four inches (4") of asphalt concrete surface course over six inches
(6") of aggregate base material over twelve inches (12") of modified subgrade/
prepared subbase.
         b.   Poor Subgrade: A "poor subgrade" is defined as a soil having an
AASHTO M-147-73 classification of A-5 (4 or greater), A-6 or A-7. Soil samples
must not exhibit a degree of expansion greater than two percent (2%) of the
sample's original height when saturated under a five hundred (500) psf load.
In poor subgrade areas, the road pavement structural section must be designed
by a registered civil engineer specializing in geotechnical or soil
engineering. The design shall be submitted to the town and include supporting
soil strength data and anticipated traffic loading for twenty (20) year design
life. All roads shall be designed for a twenty (20) year life unless prior
approval to use another design life is obtained.
Subgrade shall be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) maximum density with
plus two percent (+2%) minus four percent (-4%) optimum moisture content.
If subbase is imported, it shall meet grading J specification. It shall be
compacted to ninety five percent (95%) maximum density with plus two percent
(+2%) minus four percent (-4%) optimum moisture content.
Base course shall meet grading W specification. It shall be compacted to ninety
five percent (95%) maximum density with plus two percent (+2%) minus four
percent (-4%) optimum moisture content.
Geotextile separation fabric shall be nonwoven.
         c.   Unacceptable Subgrade: Any one of the following qualities shall
define an unacceptable subgrade:
            (1)   Soil exhibiting a degree expansion greater than two percent
(2%) of the original height when saturated under a five hundred (500) psf load,
            (2)   Soil containing organic matter, deleterious materials or
frozen soil, and
            (3)   Areas of poor drainage with saturated soil.
Areas of unacceptable subgrade shall have the soil removed and replaced with
acceptable fill. Minimum depth of removal and replacement shall be the depth of
traffic loading influence. Structural section design shall be dictated by the
type of fill imported: poor subgrade or good to fair subgrade.
         d.   Subgrade: "Subgrade" is defined by the AASHTO M-146-70 as the
prepared and compacted soil immediately below the structural section and
extending to such depth as will affect the structural design. The subgrade may
be imported fill, cut areas or undisturbed recompacted to a minimum relative
compaction of ninety percent (90%) for fine grain soils and ninety three
percent (93%) for granular soils based upon the soil's maximum density as
determined by the AASHTO T-180 test method. Soil moisture during compaction
shall be within the range of three percent (3%) drier to one percent (1%)
wetter than the optimum amount as determined above. Scarification, soil
moisture adjustment, and compaction shall be monitored and tested by an
independent engineering and soil testing laboratory. Sufficient quality control
testing shall be conducted to statistically evaluate conformance to standards.
         e.   Subbase: If a subbase is incorporated as one of the structural
section components, it shall be of sufficient quality to meet the following
requirements:
R value: Seventy (70) minimum.
CBR: Thirty five (35) minimum.
Expansion less than one percent (1%) (when saturated under a 500 psf load).
Classification: A-1 to A-3 (AASHTO-M-147).
No deleterious materials.
Minimum thickness: Four inches (4").
The subbase shall be compacted to a minimum relative compaction of ninety five
percent (95%) of the maximum density as determined by the AASHTO T-180 test
method. Moisture content during compaction shall be within the range of plus
two percent (+2%) less than minus four percent (-4%) greater than the optimum
moisture content as determined above. Both quality of material and quality of
placement shall be monitored by an engineering and testing laboratory.
         f.   Aggregate Base: The aggregate base material shall conform to the
state of Wyoming department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road
And Bridge Construction", grading "W" or better. Minimum thickness of compacted
base shall be six inches (6"). The base shall be compacted to a minimum
relative of ninety five percent (95%) of the maximum density as determined by
the AASHTO T-180 test method. Moisture content during compaction shall be
within the range of plus two percent (+2%) less than minus four percent (-4%)
greater than the optimum moisture content as determined above. Both quality of
material and quality of placement shall be monitored by an engineering and
testing laboratory.
         g.   Asphalt Concrete Surfacing: Type II, one-half inch (1/2") maximum
asphalt concrete hot mix conforming to the state of Wyoming department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" shall
be used for the surface course. The aggregate base material shall also conform
to the state of Wyoming department of transportation "Standard Specifications
For Road And Bridge Construction" for grade "W" or better. The modified
subgrade/prepared subbase shall be scarified full depth, moisture adjusted
accordingly, and recompacted in accordance with the procedure outline in
subsequent sections. Surface courses shall be a minimum thickness of two inches
(2").
All other lifts of asphalt shall use a three-fourths inch (3/4") maximum
asphalt concrete hot mix conforming to state of Wyoming department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" and
shall be a minimum of two inches (2") thick. If required by loading and design
parameters, subsequent lifts may be placed using the three-fourths inch (3/4")
mix.
All sections shall be designed by an engineer registered in the state of
Wyoming. The design shall be included in the soils report.
A current mix design shall be submitted to the town two (2) weeks before start
of the paving operation. The mix design shall address Marshall stability (ASTM
D 1159-76), resistance to plastic flow (ASTM D 1159-76), air void content (ASTM
D 3203-75), and theoretical maximum specific gravity (ASTM D 2041-78). The
recommended asphalt content with acceptable limits will be specified. The
asphalt concrete mix shall conform to the following standards:
Minimum Marshall stability (50 blow Marshall) shall be one thousand two hundred
(1,200) psf,
Plastic flow shall be within the range of eight (8) to eighteen hundredths (18/
100) of an inch,
Air voids shall be within the range of three percent (3%) to five percent (5%),
Voids in mineral aggregate shall be no less than fifteen percent (15%).
Asphalt cement shall be PG64-22 or equivalent without polymers.
The asphalt concrete mix shall be compacted to a minimum density of ninety
seven percent (97%) of the maximum as determined by the ASTM D 1159-76. A
sufficient number of in place density tests shall be performed by an
independent engineering testing firm to allow for statistical evaluation of
conformance to required standards.
         h.   Engineering Design: Consideration will be given on a site
specific basis to modification of these standards. Design and recommendations
in conflict with these standards must be prepared and submitted by a Wyoming
state registered engineer for consideration.
   S.   Alleys:
      1.   Alleys in commercial, business, and industrial zones shall be
surfaced with either AC or PCC pavements in accordance with the requirements
for street construction.
      2.   Alleys in residential zones shall be surfaced with either AC or
crushed gravel.
   T.   Sidewalks, Curbs And Gutters, Curbwalks:
      1.   Standard Detail: The Casper approved standard detail for curb and
gutter, curbwalk, and sidewalk shall be incorporated into all street design.
      2.   ADA Compliance: All improvements shall be ADA compliant. Provide ADA
features as required by law and the town.
   U.   Curb Cuts:
      1.   Residential Areas:
         a.   Minimum width: Twelve feet (12').
         b.   Only one curb cut allowed on frontages less than sixty feet
(60').
         c.   No more than two (2) curb cuts allowed on any single platted lot.
         d.   A separation of twenty five feet (25') of full (nondepressed)
vertical curb is required between curb cuts serving a single platted lot or
adjacent lots under one ownership. Townhouse, condominium, twin home, and
duplex developments are excepted.
         e.   Corner lots:
            (1)   No curb cut shall be closer than twenty five feet (25') to
the projected curb line of the intersecting street.
            (2)   Curb cuts shall not be placed closer than five feet (5') to a
side property line. Joint curb cuts for townhouses, condominiums, and duplexes
are allowed.
      2.   Industrial And Commercial Areas:
         a.   Minimum width: Twelve feet (12').
Maximum width: Thirty five feet (35').
         b.   Each platted lot shall be allowed either: one two-way curb cut or
two (2) one-way curb cuts. Exceptions:
            (1)   Property frontages are too narrow to satisfy minimum driveway
spacing requirements. Common access at property lines, frontage roads,
restricted curb cut designs, or other modifications may be required contingent
on the approval of the town.
            (2)   Additional driveways may be allowed if shown to be warranted
through traffic studies.
            (3)   If traffic studies indicate traffic volumes will meet any
signal warrant, access traffic shall be consolidated to a single signalized
point.
            (4)   Where a property has frontages on more than one street,
accesses are allowed on only the frontages where standards can be met. If
access standards cannot be met on any frontage, access points shall be
designated by the town based on traffic safety, operational needs, and traffic
studies.
      3.   Curb Cuts On Collector And Arterial Streets:
         a.   Curb cuts on opposite sides of collector and arterial streets
shall be placed as not to interfere with each other as follows:
            (1)   Placed directly opposite is the most desirable. If this is
not possible;
            (2)   Minimum spacing of the resulting "T" shall be as follows:
One hundred feet (100') on collector streets.
Two hundred feet (200') on arterial streets.
         b.   The town may modify these spacings based on existing through
traffic and site trip generation. However, in no case shall spacing be less
than seventy five feet (75').
      4.   Driveway Spacing For Collector And Arterial Streets:
         a.   Minimum Spacing: The following minimums shall apply:
 
Speed (mph) Minimum Separation (Feet)
30          125
35          150
40          185
45          230
50          275
 
Additional lanes may be required to provide for turning and exiting vehicles.
         b.   Signalized Curb Cuts: There shall be a minimum of one thousand
two hundred feet (1,200') between any two (2) signalized curb cuts.
      5.   Streets Of Different Widths: When a new roadway is constructed that
will connect directly to an existing roadway of a different width, a transition
taper shall be constructed between the two. The length of the taper will depend
on the offset difference of the traveled edge of the two (2) roadway segments.
Minimum ratio of transition length to offset shall be as follows:
 
Speed  Ratio
30 mph 10:1
30 mph 15:1
 
      6.   Access To State Highways:
         a.   Within the town access onto state highways is subject to approval
of the Wyoming department of transportation (WYDOT) and the town.
      7.   Street Lighting Installed By PacifiCorp: Rocky Mountain's Power or
current municipal electric company.
         a.   Minimum requirements:

      8.   Traffic Control Systems:
         a.   General: All traffic control systems, devices, signage, and
markings shall be designed in accordance with the latest state approved edition
of the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices" (MUTCD).
      9.   Islands And Other Raised Structures Within Street Right Of Way:
         a.   Side slopes shall be less than three to one (3:1); six to one (6:
1) is recommended.
         b.   Overall height, including height of full growth plantings, must
be less than thirty inches (30") above the roadway.
         c.   Lighting shall be directed toward and illuminate the island
rather than be directed toward traffic.
      10.   Pedestrian Lighting:
         a.   Pedestrian lighting for the downtown street shall consist of pole
King Luminaire, or approved equal. Poles shall have 15A/120V duplex receptacle,
C/W weatherproof cover plate, painted black. The globe shall be acrylic with
K12 capital painted black. Other pedestrian lighting in parks and along other
street corridors shall be approved of by the town engineer.
         b.   Poles may be single, triple or five (5) globe fixtures. Poles
shall be installed as per the manufacturer's requirements. All poles shall have
240V-100W lamps with negative twenty degree Fahrenheit (-20°F) starting
temperature ballast. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-6-5: WATER AND SEWER:
   A.   Authority:
      1.   Reference the Wyoming department of environmental quality, Wyoming
Statutes. Specifically Wyoming Statutes section 35-11-301 stipulates that no
person, except when authorized by permit, shall construct, install, or modify
any public water supply, sewerage system, treatment works, disposal system, or
other facility capable of causing or contributing to pollution.
      2.   Consult with the town of Bar Nunn (title 6, chapter 2, "Sewer Use
Regulations", of this code) and the Wardwell water district for requirements
pertaining to permitting, construction and related requirements for water
distribution and sanitary sewer systems.
   B.   Jurisdiction: These standards shall apply to the design and
construction of all public or private water distribution and sanitary sewer
mains and appurtenances (except for private pump stations), including additions
to or replacements of the existing sanitary sewer system. Public water
distribution and sanitary sewer mains, and appurtenances are defined as any
part of the water distribution or sanitary sewer system owned or controlled by
the Wardwell water district or the town of Bar Nunn and which are within public
streets, roadways, alleys, and easements. Private water distribution and
sanitary sewer mains, and appurtenances are defined as being connected to the
Wardwell water system or the town of Bar Nunn system but which are not owned by
either entity and are generally outside of public streets, alleys, or
easements.
   C.   Related Regulations:
      1.   All water distribution and sewerage collection facilities shall be
designed and constructed in compliance with applicable Wyoming department of
environmental quality regulations. Nothing contained herein shall be
interpreted to reduce those requirements.
      2.   Consult the city of Casper "Standard Specifications For Public Works
Construction And Infrastructure Improvements" (hereinafter referred to as
"standard construction specifications") and Wardwell water district.
      3.   Consult existing rules, regulations, and policies regarding water
and sewer service.
   D.   Water And Sewer Agreements: For all plats, replats, and extensions of
water and sewer service, a subdivision agreement or water and sewer service
contract must be consummated. All outside town agreements must be approved by
both the town of Bar Nunn and the Wardwell water district.
   E.   Preliminary Report:
      1.   Contents: When any new development requires subdivision approval by
the town of Bar Nunn, a preliminary report shall be submitted at the same time
as the preliminary plat or replat is submitted. All preliminary reports must be
received and approved by the town prior to preparation of final construction
drawings. The preliminary report must include the following:
         a.   A description of the development service area including a scaled
vicinity map. A review of existing adjacent facilities, including fire
hydrants, water mains, and sewer mains within three hundred feet (300') of the
proposed development, must be included.
         b.   Applicable engineering design criteria, e.g.,
            (1)   Sanitary sewers: Average flows, maximum day flows, peak
flows, industrial-commercial flows, persons per acre or per unit, etc., and
preliminary sizing and design.
            (2)   Water distribution: See Wardwell water district.
         c.   Capacities and facilities required to provide service for the
proposed development. All facilities must be sized and located in accordance
with the plans and studies of Bar Nunn; provided, however, the town reserves,
and has the right to specify, sizes and locations, including those not
otherwise delineated on the master plans.
         d.   Proposed method of achieving the desired service, including
feasible alternatives.
         e.   General layout of the proposed system, including fire hydrant
locations, with indications of any proposed staged development.
         f.   Character of soil through which mains will be laid. (Soil
resistivity measurements may be required.)
      2.   Construction Plans: After approval of the preliminary report, the
consultant can prepare construction plans for the sewage collection system and/
or the water distribution system in accordance with the approved preliminary
report, standard construction specifications and this chapter.
   F.   Booster Stations And Water Storage Tanks: See Wardwell water district.
   G.   Sewage Pumping Stations And Force Mains: The consultant shall work with
the town to develop design criteria for all publicly owned sewage pumping
stations and force mains. Any subdivision requiring the construction of a new
sewage pumping station and force main may be required to participate fully in
the cost of design and construction.
      1.   Pump stations requirements shall include, but not be limited to, the
following: An aboveground building (either concrete or masonry) shall include
control systems, SCADA backup power generation, air compressors, and
miscellaneous support equipment all of which shall be inside the building.
      2.   Wet wells shall not have ladders. Wet wells shall include backup
pumps in case of failure and shall include a grinding mechanism such as either
grinder pumps or in-line grinders. Pump rails shall be stainless steel.
   H.   Permits Required:
      1.   The town engineer and DEQ shall review and approve the plans and
specifications for all public or private sewerage collection facilities.
   I.   Record Drawings: The "record" drawings must include the following
information for water and sanitary sewer and stormwater facilities:
      1.   Contractor's name and address.
      2.   Construction dates.
      3.   Distance between water or sewer mains and other utilities.
      4.   Street names and widths (ROW widths and paved widths).
      5.   Mains and sizes.
      6.   Material of mains.
      7.   Fire hydrant locations and manufacturer, and model.
      8.   Water valve locations and types of all anodes.
      9.   Location of corrosion test stations.
      10.   Location of tracer/locator boxes.
      11.   Distances from property lines.
      12.   Block and lot numbers.
      13.   Street addresses. These may be obtained from the town.
      14.   Measurement from sewer main to stub-out end. Ends of stub- outs
must be tied into permanent reference points and elevations shown.
      15.   Measurements from water main to curb box. Also all curb stops must
be tied into permanent reference points.
      16.   Sizes of taps.
      17.   Distance between fittings.
      18.   All dead ends accurately tied into permanent reference points.
      19.   All tapping sleeves shall be shown.
      20.   All couplings shall be indicated.
      21.   Location of all bends (including vertical bends).
      22.   Size of sewer taps.
      23.   All manhole invert and top of ring elevations.
      24.   Distance between manholes or cleanouts.
      25.   Orientation of north.
      26.   Scales must be the same scale as those for construction drawings.
      27.   Sewer shall include slopes.
      28.   Schedule and/or classification of materials.
      29.   Stationing.
      30.   Shall be twenty four inch by thirty six inch (24" x 36") or eleven
inch by seventeen inch (11" x 17") sheet sizes.
      31.   Developer's name, address, and contact information.
      32.   Pumping stations, lift stations, and booster stations shall include
vault sizes and types, building details, pump details, electric, SCADA, piping
diagrams, manufacturer cut sheets and start up procedures.
      33.   Shall be submitted on four (4) mil mylar and in electronic "CAD"
format readable by the town.
   J.   Oversizing:
      1.   All oversized (10 inches and above) sewer mains shall be installed
in accordance with the town's master plan of wastewater facilities as
applicable. All sewer mains are to be installed by the developer at their
expense. The town may elect to reimburse the developer an amount for
oversizing.
      2.   The town may, at its sole discretion, pay for oversizing costs of
sewer mains. The calculation for reimbursement shall be:
Twice the subtraction amount arrived at by taking the cost of eight inch (8")
sewer main material from the oversized sewer main material cost.
      3.   All sewer service line installations are the sole responsibility of
the developer.
   K.   Preliminary Acceptance/Substantial Completion:
      1.   Sanitary Sewer: Prior to preliminary acceptance of a sanitary sewer
system, regardless of ownership, the following inspection tests shall be made
and certified for each section of sewer (not applicable for townhouse manifold
systems):
         a.   The acceptance will depend upon certified submitted passing tests
and items listed in city of Casper section 601.11 of the standard construction
specification.
      2.   Water Distribution: Prior to preliminary acceptance of the water
system, regardless of ownership, the Wardwell water district shall make a
recommendation of substantial and final acceptance.
         a.   If allowed by the water and sewer contract or the subdivision
agreement, and the water agreement with Wardwell water district, the town may
recommend the issuance of building permits following preliminary acceptance.
   L.   Final Acceptance:
      1.   Refer to the city of Casper standard construction specifications
section 501.14b and 601.11c.
      2.   If a developer or owner does not proceed in an expeditious manner to
obtain final acceptance, the town engineer may recommend against the issuance
of remaining building permits.
      3.   No oversizing contribution will be made until after final
acceptance.
      4.   Upon final acceptance, public systems shall become the property of
the town of Bar Nunn. The developer shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of
the town engineer that no liens have been or will be filed upon the facilities
that have been installed and are to become the property of the town, e.g., lien
waivers. The warranty period shall not start until final acceptance is obtained
in the case of subdivisions. (Ord. 2012-04, 7-17-2012)
9-6-6: WATER FACILITIES:
   A.   General: Water facilities shall be approved by the Wardwell water
district before construction starts.
All designs shall be in accordance with these standards; the Wyoming department
of environmental quality water quality rules and regulations, chapter XII; the
uniform plumbing code, as adopted by the town of Bar Nunn; Wardwell water
district; and other town master plans, ordinances, rules and regulations and
policies.
No concrete pads (diamonds) shall be placed around valve boxes in paved
streets. Valve boxes shall be placed a minimum of one-half inch (1/2") to a
maximum of one inch (1") below the finished paved surface.
   B.   Irrigation Systems (Town Facilities And Properties): All irrigation
systems shall be approved by the town before installation of the system. An
irrigation system shall consist of irrigation controller boxes, reduced
pressure and backflow prevention devices and enclosures, meter pedestals, pump
and enclosures, electrical panels, etc.
      1.   All exposed equipment such as irrigation controller boxes, reduced
pressure backflow prevention device enclosures, meter pedestals, pump
enclosures, electrical panels, etc., shall be powder coated green to match the
"strong box" color RAL 6005 or Cardinal industrial finishes #T007-GN16 traffic
green. If the items cannot be powder coated prior to installation, they may be
field painted to match the above.
      2.   Irrigation shall be designed to irrigate the entire area no more
than eight (8) hours a day at the rate of one-half inch (1/2") per eight (8)
hour period, to apply two inches (2") of precipitation over four (4) days.
      3.   Type of controller shall be designated by town of Bar Nunn prior to
bid.
      4.   Tree watering to provide five (5) gpm, per tree, and number of days
per week according to soil conditions. Install a three- fourths inch (3/4")
quick coupling at the end of the line to winterize the system. Winter watering
shall be done by contractor.
      5.   The entire irrigation and water system shall be guaranteed for a
period of one year from date of acceptance by the owner.
      6.   Contractor shall provide record drawings with location of all buried
piping, wiring and other improvements.
      7.   Any irrigation placed under asphalt and/or cement shall be blown out
(winterized) first, by the contractor, to prevent possible freeze breaks while
still under warranty.
      8.   Any irrigation placed under asphalt and/or cement shall be installed
in PVC pipe sleeves of at least schedule 80 and a minimum of three inches (3")
in diameter and shall be of sufficient size to accommodate the irrigation pipe
to be installed later.
      9.   All reduced pressure backflow preventers, water meters, and blowouts
shall be checked by authorized personnel before using.
      10.   Sprinklers to be adjusted to arc or full circle to meet coverage
needs. Straighten and adjust heads to proper height.
      11.   Swing joints must be installed on same side as PVC pipe. It may not
cross the PVC laterally.
      12.   Thrust blocks may not exceed twelve inches by twelve inches (12" x
