   D.   Any vehicle other than the vehicle of the funeral service or mortuary
company, shall be required to register with the Bar Nunn police department
prior to leading any funeral processions.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
CHAPTER 14
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
10-14-1: Loitering In Crosswalk
10-14-2: Crossing Streets In Business District Or School Zones
10-14-1: LOITERING IN CROSSWALK:
   All pedestrians crossing streets or roadways in marked or unmarked
crosswalks shall not loiter in the crosswalk.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-14-2: CROSSING STREETS IN BUSINESS DISTRICT OR SCHOOL ZONES:
   It is unlawful for any pedestrian to cross any street within the central
business district of the town to cross any street within any school zone within
the town, except at marked or indicated crosswalks which shall be provided by
the town.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
CHAPTER 15
PLAY STREETS
SECTION:
10-15-1: Establishment Authorized When
10-15-2: Driving Restrictions
10-15-1: ESTABLISHMENT AUTHORIZED WHEN:
   The Town Council shall have authority to declare any street or part thereof
a play street and to place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway
indicating and helping to protect the same.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-15-2: DRIVING RESTRICTIONS:
   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof
as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or
portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences
are within such closed area, and then any driver shall exercise the greatest
care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
CHAPTER 16
TRUCK TRAFFIC
SECTION:
10-16-1: Definitions
10-16-2: Application Of Chapter Provisions
10-16-3: Exempt Vehicles Designated
10-16-4: Authority To Weigh And Measure
10-16-5: Height, Width And Tires–Permit Conditions
10-16-6: Operation On Non-Truck-Route Streets
10-16-7: Designation Of Truck Routes
10-16-8: Map Maintenance Authority
10-16-9: Violation–Penalty
10-16-1: DEFINITIONS:
DEVIATING TRUCK: A truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while
traveling inside the town.
LOAD: The weight or quantity of anything being transported by a truck.
OVERSIZE LOAD: A load, fixed or unfixed, that exceeds the size limits set forth
in this chapter.
OVERWEIGHT LOAD: A load, fixed or unfixed, that exceeds the weight limits set
forth in this chapter.
PERMIT: A written authorization to move or operate on a highway a vehicle or
vehicles with load of size or weight exceeding the limits as specified by this
chapter.
STREETS OF DESTINATION: Any street inside the town not designated as a truck
route.
STREETS OF THE TOWN: "Street" means and includes public streets, avenues,
boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the
approaches thereto, and all other public thoroughfares in the town, and, as
designated by this chapter, allows for the operation of truck traffic.
TIRE, PNEUMATIC: "Pneumatic tire" means a tire of rubber or other resilient
material which depends on compressed air for support of a load.
TRUCK: Any vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the
transportation of property, and whose rated load capacity exceeds two tons. For
the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
TRUCK ROUTE: A public way within the town, as designated in this chapter, over
and along which trucks must operate.
UNLADEN WEIGHT: The actual weight of a vehicle, including the cab, body, and
all accessories with which the vehicle is equipped for normal use on highways,
excluding the weight of any load. The unladen weight of vehicles mounted with
machinery or equipment not normally designed for the vehicle and not used for
the transportation of property other than the machinery or equipment is three-
fourths of the gross weight of the vehicle.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-2: APPLICATION OF CHAPTER PROVISIONS:
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the operation of trucks within
the town, except to the extent that such provisions are in conflict with state
or federal law.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-3: EXEMPT VEHICLES DESIGNATED:
   This chapter shall not prohibit:
   A.   Emergency Vehicles. The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street
in the town;
   B.   Detoured Vehicles. The operation of trucks upon any officially
established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon
the street for which such detour is established;
   C.   School Buses. The operation of public or private school buses upon any
street in the town;
   D.   Government Maintenance Vehicles. The operation of government
maintenance vehicles upon any street in the town.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-4: AUTHORITY TO WEIGH AND MEASURE:
   The Chief of Town Maintenance, or his appointee, shall have the authority to
require the driver of any truck operating on the streets of the town, and which
he has reason to believe is overweight or oversize, to proceed with the truck
to an appropriate weight station or stopping place for the purpose of
determining whether this chapter has been complied with.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-5: HEIGHT, WIDTH AND TIRES–PERMIT CONDITIONS:
   A.   No truck, unladen or with load or load-holding devices thereon, in
excess of eight and one-half feet (8.5') in width and/or fourteen feet (14') in
height, shall be driven upon any Town street without a special use permit.
   B.   The wheels of all trucks shall be equipped with pneumatic tires. In
special cases, trucks hauling single items of machinery or equipment which
cannot be readily dismantled or divided, and the size of such vehicles exceeds
the limits herein prescribed, may be operated provided a special use permit has
been obtained from the State Highway Superintendent and chief engineer, except
that trucks operating on the streets of the Town shall first secure permission
of the Chief of Town Maintenance.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-6: OPERATION ON NON-TRUCK-ROUTE STREETS:
   The operation of trucks over and along any Town street not designated a
truck route, shall be permitted only for the purpose of reaching a point of
destination inside the Town, provided that:
   A.   One Destination Point. All trucks having a single destination point in
the Town shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate
only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted
nearest to the destination point. A deviating truck shall return to the truck
route by the shortest possible route;
   B.   Multiple Destination Points. All trucks having multiple destination
points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only
at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted,
nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination
point, a deviating truck shall return to the nearest truck route, and proceed
to other destination points by the shortest direction, and only over streets
upon which such traffic is permitted. Upon leaving the last destination point,
a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible
route;
   C.   Routes for Construction as designated by the Town Engineer. The Town
Engineer may appoint a truck route as part of construction site plans or
construction activities.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-7: DESIGNATION OF TRUCK ROUTES:
   The Chief of Town Maintenance after consultation with appropriate department
heads shall have the authority to designate truck routes within the Town of Bar
Nunn.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-8: MAP MAINTENANCE AUTHORITY:
   The Town engineer shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck
routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted; the maps shall be
kept on file in the office of the Town engineer and shall be available to the
public.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-16-9: VIOLATION–PENALTY:
   It is unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated any truck
within the Town in violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
CHAPTER 17
SNOW AND SPECIAL ROUTES
SECTION:
10-17-1: Snow Routes
10-17-2: Definitions
10-17-3: Snow Routes Designated
10-17-4: Prohibitions, Penalties And Enforcement
10-17-1: SNOW ROUTES:
   The following provisions shall apply to designated Snow Routes within the
Town of Bar Nunn.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-17-2: DEFINITIONS:
   The Following Definitions shall apply to this Chapter.
PARK(ED): The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a street.
Park(ed) does not include stopping temporarily for the purpose of, and while
actually engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers, or loading or
unloading merchandise, or in obedience to traffic regulations, signs or
signals, or any involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond
the control of the operator.
SNOW EVENT: Any accumulation of snowfall that requires designated snow routes
to be plowed by the town of Bar Nunn.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-17-3: SNOW ROUTES DESIGNATED:
   The following routes are designated as snow routes from October 1 through
March 31:
   A.   Both sides of the street, Sunset Boulevard from Salt Creek Highway to
the west end of the street.
   B.   Both sides of the street, Tipton Street beginning at the Rimrock
intersection, then east across Antelope Drive and Bel Vista Drive.
   C.   Both sides of the street, Siebke Drive from Mustang Trail to the Bar
Nunn School Parking Lot.
   D.   Both sides of the street, Mustang Trail in its entirety.
   E.   Both sides of the street, McMurry Boulevard from Salt Creek Highway to
the dead end portion west of Antelope Drive.
   F.   Both sides of the street, Nez Perce Trail north from McMurry Boulevard
through the dead end portion north of Zuni Trail.
   G.   Both sides of the street, Tonkawa Trail north from McMurry Boulevard
through the intersection with Zuni Trail.
   H.   Both sides of the street, all dead-end street portions of Mandan,
Absaroka, Omaha, Sioux, Lakota, Inca, Kalina and Zuni Trails.
   I.   Both sides of the street, Antelope Drive from McMurry Boulevard to the
dead end north of Zuni Trail.
   J.   East side of the west side of the street, Antelope Drive from Salt
Creek Highway to McMurry Boulevard.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
10-17-4: PENALTIES AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Prohibition: If a snow event occurs during the months of October 1 of
any year through March 31 of the next succeeding year, no person shall park any
vehicle on a designated snow route street, or part thereof
   B.   Penalties And Enforcement: Any violation of this section shall
constitute a misdemeanor. Any violation of this section that continues for a
period of twenty-four (24) hours or more shall constitute a new and separate
distinct violation.
      1.   A duly appointed law enforcement officer authorized to act on behalf
of the town may:
         a.   Issue a ticket to the owner of any vehicle that is parked in
violation of this section; and/or
         b.   Have the offending vehicle towed, impounded, and stored if said
vehicle:
            (1)   In the officer's discretion, creates a hazard or hinders the
removal of snow; and/or
            (2)   Has not been removed from the snow route within twenty-four
(24) hours after the issuance of the ticket.
         c.   Any vehicle towed, impounded, and/or stored pursuant to this
section may be released as otherwise provided for in this title. Any damage
occurring to any vehicle as the result of the towing, impounding, and storage
of the vehicle conducted pursuant to the terms of this section shall be the
sole and separate responsibility or obligation of the titled owner or person in
charge or having possession of the vehicle. The town shall bear no
responsibility or obligation for any such damage.
         c.   Any damage occurring to a vehicle located within a designated
snow route street, or part thereof, as the result of the towing, impounding,
and storage of the vehicle, or as a result of the plowing and removal of snow
from designated snow route streets, or parts thereof, by town employees and/or
agents, shall be the sole and separate responsibility or obligation of the
title owner or person in charge or having possession of the vehicle. The town
shall bear no responsibility or obligation for such damage.
(Ord. 2022-07, 12-20-2022)
TITLE 11
RESERVED
TITLE 12
RESERVED
TITLE 13
PUBLIC SERVICES
CHAPTER 1
WATER SYSTEM
ARTICLE A. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND INFORMATION
SECTION:
13-1A-1: Duties Of Governing Body
13-1A-2: Powers And Duties Of Public Works Director
13-1A-3: Distribution And Treatment
13-1A-4: Interfering Or Tampering With Waterworks–Polluting Water Supply
13-1A-5: Maintenance Of Service Lines
13-1A-6: Water Meters–Required
13-1A-7: Installation Of Meters–Generally
13-1A-8: Right Of Access To Meters
13-1A-9: Ownership Of Meters–Maintenance
13-1A-10: Responsibility For Taps Or Connections To Water Mains
13-1A-11: Curb Stops–Installation And Access
13-1A-1: DUTIES OF GOVERNING BODY:
   Subject to the laws relating to public utilities, the governing body shall
fix all rates for water charges, tap fees and for services inside and outside
the corporate limits of the town and make regulations as appropriate.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR
   A.   The Public Works Director or the Town Clerk, or 'his/her authorized
representative, shall enforce all necessary rules, regulations, and penalties
to enforce the collection of fees or for the protection of the property and
rights pertaining to the town's waterworks system. This authority shall include
the power to make administrative rules or regulations as may be necessary to
conserve the water supply and to prevent waste and unnecessary use of water,
including water restrictions.
   B.   The director of public works, or his/her designated representative, is
authorized to issue a shutoff notice to any person who is two (2) months
delinquent in payment of any water bill. Such person's water shall be shut off
pursuant to Section 13-1E-7 if the bill is not paid in full
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-3: DISTRIBUTION AND TREATMENT:
   The director of public works shall be responsible for the distribution and
treatment of the town's water system from the source of supply to service lines
on the property side of the curb.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-4: INTERFERING OR TAMPERING WITH WATERWORKS-POLLUTING WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   No unauthorized person shall in any way interfere or tamper with any
part of the town's water system, nor shall they do anything that will in any
manner pollute or cause to pollute the water supply. Any person found guilty of
polluting or tampering with the town's water supply shall be subject to a
maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   B.   No unauthorized person shall in any manner tamper with, deface or
injure any fire hydrant nor shall the same be obstructed by any person in any
manner so that free access to such hydrant cannot be readily had at all times
for firefighting purposes. Any person found guilty of these acts shall be
subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-5: MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE LINES:
   A.   All property owners and consumers of water shall keep and maintain the
service line beginning at the property side of the curb stop or upstream side
of meter pit where there is no curb stop and shall keep the line in good repair
and protect it from frost at their own expense.
   B.   The town shall not be responsible for payment of any claim resulting
from the breakage of any pipe, meter or appurtenance attached thereto if the
breakage occurs on the property side of the curb stop.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-6: WATER METERS-REQUIRED:
   A.   All water delivered to any water users by means of the water system of
the Town shall be measured by meters.
   B.   Each single-family dwelling, multi-family building, business structure
or mobile home park shall have a separate water meter. Condominiums, townhouses
and/or duplex units shall be considered single-family units and shall have
separate meters and shutoffs if each unit is individually owned.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-7: INSTALLATION OF METERS-GENERALLY:
   A.   As included in the fees set forth in Section
13-1C-1, the Town shall supply all meters installed in the Town water system.
All meters shall be installed with remote readout located on the outside of the
structure or at the meter pit and accessible at all times to authorized
personnel.
   B.   Meters shall be a minimum of three-fourths inch (3/4") inlet size for
all meters installed following the effective date of this chapter. No pipes or
other objects shall be installed in front of or adjacent to the meter.
Sufficient room for removal of the meter must be available. Swivel connections
shall be used and at least one-inch (1") flexibility must be maintained in
pipes to which meters are connected for proper removal for maintenance. All
water meters shall be installed in meter pits as specified in the latest
edition of the City of Casper, Wyoming's Standard Specifications. Meters two
inches (2") in diameter and larger shall be installed in reinforced concrete
vaults; the design of the meter vaults shall be submitted to the Town for
approval prior to construction.
   C.   An isolation valve must be installed in front of and behind the meter
in order to allow isolation of the meter.
   D.   Any compound meter installed shall be installed horizontally to allow
for proper repair and maintenance.
   E.   Each meter installed shall be protected by a Town-approved seal. The
seal shall not be broken without the public works director's approval. Splices
of any type will not be allowed in any readout cable and shall be considered as
tampering with Town property. No person shall tamper with readout cables or
meter seals, install an illegal tap, bypass or in any way remove water from the
Town's system without going through the proper metered facility. Any person
found guilty of a violation of this subsection shall be subject to a fine not
to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-8: RIGHT OF ACCESS TO METERS:
   The public works director, meter technician, or other authorized personnel
of the Town shall have free access at all reasonable hours to enter any
premises where water is used, for the purpose of ascertaining any violation of
any provisions of this chapter and to read, inspect, repair or remove for
testing any water meter.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-9: OWNERSHIP OF METERS-MAINTENANCE:
   A.   All meters and remote readouts, including cable, are the property of
the Town.
   B.   The owner of the property upon which a meter is located shall assure
that such meter is at all times in good working order, and shall contact the
public works director to cause the meter to be repaired or replaced. The
property owner shall bear all cost of maintenance except for normal wear from
operation.
   C.   Town utility personnel shall remove and replace the meter if found
defective and, unless damaged by the property owner or occupant, shall do so at
no cost to the property owner.
   D.   If the property owner requests a test to verify meter accuracy, the
meter shall be removed and tested by Town personnel, a certified testing
vendor, or by a tester employed by a Natrona County municipality qualified to
do the same. All costs associated with testing shall be the responsibility of
the property owner if no malfunction of the meter is found. If the meter is
found to be faulty, the Town shall pay all costs of meter testing.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-10: RESPONSIBILITY FOR TAPS OR CONNECTIONS TO WATER MAINS:
   A.   All taps or connections into any water main of the Town shall be
completed under the direction and supervision of an authorized employee of the
Town and subject to material and method approval by the Town. No substitutions
are allowed unless approval in writing is granted by the public works director.
All tap's, materials, and plumbing must be inspected by town personnel before
any taps are to buried.
   B.   Any cost for taps including excavation, materials, tools, backfill,
compaction and resurfacing of streets, and replacement of curb, gutter and
sidewalks shall be done at the full expense of the property owner, developer or
contractor.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1A-11: CURB STOPS–INSTALLATION AND ACCESS:
   A.   Curb stops shall be furnished and installed by a contractor licensed to
work in the Town for all structures to be served with water.
   B.   Single-family dwellings and businesses shall have curb stops installed
within five feet (5') of the property line, at the back of the sidewalk if
space allows; or within the sidewalk if the sidewalk abuts a building, set
level with the sidewalk, and such curb stops shall be of a ferrous, metallic
composition to allow for location by a magnetic or conductance locator.
   C.   Multiple-family dwellings shall have one (1) curb stop located within
the public right-of-way as determined by the Town, which shall provide shutoff
service to the entire facility.
   D.   No person shall deposit any dirt or other material on or in any public
curb box, valve box, or tamper in any way to prevent the use of such by the
Town or its agents.
   E.   No person shall park any vehicle, or otherwise block access to a curb
stop for the purpose of prevention of shutting, opening, or any other use of
the curb stop. Persons refusing to move vehicles may be subjected to towing at
the owner's cost.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE B. CROSS-CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW CONTROL
SECTION:
13-1B-1: Purpose
13-1B-2: Definitions
13-1B-3: Responsibility
13-1B-4: Degree Of Hazard
13-1B-5: Residential Water Service Connections
13-1B-6: New Residential Water Users
13-1B-7: Commercial, Industrial, Or Other High Hazard Water Users
13-1B-8: Standards For Installation Of Backflow Prevention Assemblies
13-1B-9: Testing And Maintenance
13-1B-10: Right Of Entry
13-1B-11: Violations
13-1B-1: PURPOSE:
   The purpose of this chapter is to comply with the Federal Safe Drinking
Water Act of 1974, the Department of Environmental Quality Water Quality Rules
and Regulations, the International Plumbing Code and to meet the following
goals:
   A.   To protect the public potable water supply of the Town from the
possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating, within its customer's
internal distribution system(s), such contaminants or pollutants which could
backflow - to back siphon - into the public water system;
   B.   To promote the elimination or control of existing cross-connections,
actual or potential, between the customer's in-plant potable water system(s)
and non-potable system(s), plumbing fixtures, and industrial piping system(s);
   C.   To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross-
connection control, which will systematically prevent the contamination or
pollution of all potable water systems.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-2: DEFINITIONS:
   The following definitions shall apply to this chapter:
APPROVED: Accepted by the public works director as meeting an applicable
specification stated or cited in this chapter or as suitable for the proposed
use.
AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY: Any water supply on or available to the water user's
premises other than the Town's approved public potable water supply.
BACK PRESSURE: A condition in which the water user's system pressure is greater
than the Town's system pressure.
BACK SIPHONAGE: The flow or water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into
the distribution pipes of the potable water supply system through any source
other than its intended source caused by the sudden reduction of pressure in
the potable water supply system.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances, under
positive or reduced pressure into the distribution pipes of the potable water
supply from any source other than its intended source.
BACKFLOW PREVENTER: An approved device or means designed to prevent backflow or
back siphonage events from contaminating the potable water supply system. The
most common devices are air gap, reduced pressure principal device, double
check valve assembly, pressure vacuum breaker, atmospheric vacuum breaker, hose
bibb vacuum breaker, residential dual check, double check with intermediate
atmospheric vent, and barometric loop.
CERTIFIED BACKFLOW PROTECTION ASSEMBLY TESTER: A person who has passed an
approved backflow protection assembly tester's certification examination.
CHECK VALVE: A self-closing assembly, which is designed to permit the flow of
fluids in one direction. A single check valve is not an approved backflow
prevention assembly.
CONTAINMENT: The practice of installing approved backflow prevention devices at
the water service connection of the water user in order to protect the public
water supply from any backflow from the water user's system.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of a public water supply by the introduction or
admission of any foreign substance which degrades the quality of the potable
water or creates a health hazard.
CROSS-CONNECTION: Any actual or potential connection between a potable water
supply and any other source or system through which it is possible to introduce
contamination into the system.
DOMESTIC SERVICES: Services using potable water for ordinary living processes
not for commercial or industrial uses, fire protection systems with antifreeze
or other chemicals, heating systems, etc. Examples may include residences,
churches, office buildings, schools, etc.
DUAL CHECK: A device conforming to the American Society of Sanitary Engineering
Standards No. 104, consisting of two (2) independently acting check valves.
Dual check valves are allowed only for residential water service connections
that have a low hazard potential with back pressure or back siphonage under
continuous pressure.
FIXTURE ISOLATION: A method of backflow prevention in which a backflow
preventer is located to correct a cross-connection at the fixture location
rather than at a water service entrance.
HAZARD CLASSIFICATION: A determination by a hazard classification surveyor as
to high hazard or low hazard and the potential cause of backflow as either back
pressure or back siphonage.
HIGH HAZARD: A situation created when any substance which is or may be
introduced into a public water supply poses a threat to public health through
poisoning, the spread of disease or pathogenic organisms, or any other public
health concern.
LOW HAZARD: A situation created when any substance which is or may be
introduced into a public water supply does not pose a threat to public health
but which does adversely affect the aesthetic quality of the potable water.
WATER SERVICE CONNECTION: Any waterline or pipe connected to a distribution
supply main or pipe for the purpose of conveying water to a water user's
system.
WATER USER: Any entity, whether public or private, with a water service
connection to a public water supply. The water user is also identified as a
customer of a public water supply.
WATER USER SYSTEM: That portion of the user's water system between the water
service connection and the point of use. This system includes all pipes,
conduits, tanks, fixtures, and appurtenances used to convey, store or utilize
water provided by the public water supply.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-3: RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   The Town has the responsibility of owning, operating, and maintaining
the public water system beginning at the source of supply and including
adequate treatment facilities, the public water distribution system and service
piping, ending at the point of delivery to the consumer's water system (service
connection meter pit).
   B.   The Town shall develop, adopt by resolution, and implement a cross-
connection control program in accordance with the minimum requirements set
forth by the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality. The Town shall
exercise reasonable, informed judgment in assessing the degree of hazard posed
to the public water system by all water users being served.
   C.   The Town building official and Director of Public Works shall be
responsible for reviewing building plans and inspection of plumbing as it is
installed, to prevent cross-connections from being designed and built into
structures within the Town's jurisdiction. The building official's inspection
responsibility begins at the curb stop connection or water meter pit and
continues throughout the entire extent of the customer's potable water system.
Approved backflow prevention devices shall be indicated on the construction
plans as determined by the degree of hazard that the inspector reasonably
determines will be present, and such devices shall be properly installed.
   D.   The water user has the primary responsibility for preventing pollutants
and contaminants from entering his/her potable water system or the public water
system. The water user's responsibility starts at the point of delivery
(service connection up-stream of meter pit) and includes all his/her internal
water system. The water user, at his/her own expense, shall install, operate,
test, and maintain approved backflow prevention devices as required by this
chapter.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-4: DEGREE OF HAZARD:
   The Town recognizes the threat to the public water system arising from
cross-connections. All threats will be classified based upon the degree of
hazard of the cross-connection and the cause of the potential backflow. Hazards
shall be classified as high hazard or low hazard. The potential cause of the
backflow shall be identified as being back siphonage or back pressure.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-5: RESIDENTIAL WATER SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
   Residential water service connections shall be considered to be low hazard,
back siphonage connections, unless determined otherwise by a hazard
classification. Residential dual check devices for structures existing at the
time of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be replaced
under a program as referenced in Section
13-1B-3(B) of this chapter and funded through the water department capital
replacement fund. Installation of residential dual check devices shall be
installed as water meters are replaced throughout the community with the goal
of installing all such systems within sixty (60) months from passage of the
ordinance codified in this chapter.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-6: NEW RESIDENTIAL WATER USERS:
   All new residential developments will be required to install a residential
dual check device at the water user's expense downstream of the water meter
before any certificate of occupancy will be issued for the structure.
   The water user shall be notified that installation of a backflow prevention
assembly device results in a potential closed plumbing system within his/her
residence. As such, provisions may have to be made by the water user to provide
for thermal expansion within his/her closed loop system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-7: COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL, OR OTHER HIGH HAZARD WATER USERS:
   A.   Commercial or industrial water users shall, at their own expense,
install, maintain, and test, or have tested, any and all backflow preventers
beyond the water service connection, pursuant to Section
13-1B-9.
   B.   Commercial or industrial water service connections shall be considered
to be high hazard back pressure connections, unless determined otherwise by the
hazard classification. For premises existing prior to the adoption of the
ordinance codified in this chapter, the Town will perform evaluation and
inspections of plans and/or premises under its cross-connection program.
      1.   If such water users are determined to be low hazard, the water user
shall be required to install appropriate cross-connection device within sixty
(60) months of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter.
      2.   If such water users are determined to be high hazard, the Town shall
notify such water user by letter of the need to install a suitable cross-
connection device or to correct any existing faulty cross-connection device
installation, the method of achieving the correction, and the time allowed for
the installation or correction to be made. In no case shall a high hazard water
service connection be allowed to delay installation or corrective action for
more than ninety (90) days from date of inspection. This time-period may be
shortened depending upon the degree of hazard involved.
   C.   Failure to comply with the designated deadline shall subject the water
user to a termination of water services within a period not to exceed five (5)
days for failure to comply with the requirements of this section. In the event
the water user informs the Town of extenuating circumstances as to why the
correction has not been made, a time extension may be granted by the department
but in no case will it exceed one thirty (30) day extension.
   D.   If the Town determines at any time that a serious threat to the public
health exists, the water service may be terminated immediately and without
prior notification.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-8: STANDARDS FOR INSTALLATION OF BACKFLOW PREVENTION ASSEMBLIES:
   A.   Before any backflow prevention assembly is installed for the prevention
of backflow, the Town shall first approve such assembly. Assembly shall be
installed and tested for conformity with recognized standards acceptable to the
Town, which are consistent with the International Plumbing Code, Town utility
construction specifications and Department of Environmental Quality
regulations.
   B.   Existing backflow prevention assembly installations that are not
approved shall be replaced with an approved assembly within ninety (90) days
written notice from Town.
   C.   Approved assemblies shall not be modified in any way after the assembly
leaves the manufacturer's factory. If installation is not completed by a
plumber licensed within Natrona County, completed installation shall be
inspected by a plumber licensed with the Town. Upon completion of installation
or inspection, the licensed plumber shall notify the Town of the installation.
   D.   Installation requirements complying with the International Plumbing
Code shall be followed in access and clearance for the required testing,
maintenance, and repair of all assemblies.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-9: TESTING AND MAINTENANCE:
   A.   It is the duty of the water user of any premises protected with a
testable backflow prevention assembly to have such assembly tested annually or
as directed by the Town, at the water user's expense.
   B.   Any assembly that leaks, malfunctions, or fails a test shall be
repaired or replaced and retested upon notification of such failure by the
tester and/or written notice from the Town of the failure within five (5)
working days of receipt of such notice. High hazard situations will not be
allowed to continue unprotected if the backflow preventer fails the test and
cannot be repaired immediately.
   C.   The Town reserves the right to spot check and test any containment
assembly at any time to verify the proper operation and test results of the
assembly.
   D.   The water user shall be responsible for the payment of all fees for
permits, device testing, retesting in the case that the device fails to operate
correctly for non-compliance with Town requirements.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-10: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
   The Town public works director, or his/her designee shall, during normal
business hours and upon display of proper credentials, have the right to enter
all buildings being served from the public water system for the purpose of
inspection of cross-connections and existing or potential hazards. The right of
entry shall be a condition of continuing water service in order to provide
assurance that the health, safety and welfare are maintained for the community
within the water distribution system of the Town.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1B-11: VIOLATIONS:
   Failure of the water user to cooperate in the installation, maintenance,
testing or inspection of backflow prevention assemblies required by the
ordinance codified in this chapter shall be grounds for the termination of
water service to the premises.
   Water service may be terminated by the Town if unprotected cross-connections
exist on the premises. When any defect is found in an installed backflow
prevention assembly, or if the backflow prevention assembly has been removed or
bypassed, water service may be terminated. Service shall not be restored until
such conditions or defects are corrected.
   Termination of service may be summary, immediate and without written notice
whenever, in the judgment of the Town, such action is necessary to protect the
purity of the public potable water system supply or the safety of the water
system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE C. SYSTEM INVESTMENT FEES
SECTION:
13-1C-1: Determination Of Amount–Responsibility
13-1C-2: Right-Of-Way Permits Required
13-1C-1: DETERMINATION OF AMOUNT–RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   All charges for connection to the Town's water system made pursuant
hereto shall be paid by the owner of the property, developer or contractor and
shall be paid to the Town upon issuance of the tap permit. A right-of-way
permit will be required for excavation onto Town right-of-way or other public
land.
   B.   The system investment fee for connections to the Town water system
shall be set by the Governing Body of the Town of Bar Nunn by resolution. For
metered connections larger than four inches (4") in diameter, the plant
investment fee shall be negotiated by the public works director based upon
projected water usage at the facility versus the maximum flow rate through a
one inch (1") diameter meter.
      1.   The base plant investment fee is assessed to new development to
cover the development's share of the system capacity, including water sources,
treatment, transmission, pumping and storage, and is intended to cover the
proposed customer's pro-rata share of these capital facilities.
      2.   Included in the total system investment fees is the cost and
installation of the meter and the remote readout and meter activation charges.
The system investment fee does not include the cost for tapping the water main
and the installation of the service line, corporation stop, curb stop, meter
pit and all associated excavation and surface restoration. The property owner,
developer or contractor will be responsible for the costs of installing the
service line to the property and the service connection pursuant to Section 13-
1A-1(B) of this chapter.
      3.   Any property served by the Town outside the corporate limits shall
be charged one and one-half (1.5) times the total plant investment fees
indicated in this section, provided however that this shall not apply to such
areas at the time of the adoption of this which may be subject to other
agreements and provisions, which shall accordingly govern.
      4.   A connection fee for a separate fire-fighting line connection shall
be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), unless modified by the Governing Body
of the Town of Bar Nunn by resolution, provided this line is not used to
provide the everyday water supply to the structure.
      5.   The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by
a resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so
determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent
resolution. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges
during the budgetary process as is necessary (to) meet the anticipated
expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect
until or unless revised in any subsequent year.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1C-2: RIGHT-OF-WAY PERMITS REQUIRED:
   A.   For excavation in Town right-of-way or other public land within the
Town, a right-of-way permit shall be obtained from the public work department.
The permit shall cover such items as: excavation, materials, backfill,
compaction, replacement of asphalt or concrete paving, replacement of curb,
gutter, and sidewalks and any other materials required for complete restoration
of the trenched area.
   B.   All excavated areas shall be compacted to Town specifications and,
prior to replacing any surfacing, contractor shall contact the community
development department for soils testing and approval of compaction.
   C.   In the case of failure of the excavation or surfacing, even with
testing, the party causing the excavation shall be fully responsible for
replacing the same for a period of one (1) year after completion of the work.
In the event the contractor refuses to repair such failure, the town may, at
its discretion, order the work to be done by another party and bill such cost
back to the original permittee.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE D. USE OF PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM REQUIRED
SECTION:
13-1D-1: Connection To Town Water System Required
13-1D-2: On-Site Water System Prohibited
13-1D-1: CONNECTION TO TOWN WATER SYSTEM REQUIRED:
   A.   The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the Town
and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located
or may in the future be located a public water distribution line of the Town,
is required at the owner's expense to install suitable potable water facilities
for each individual residence and/or commercial business and each separate
property owner therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public water line in accordance with the provisions of this division and
adopted public works standards within ninety (90) days after date of official
notice to do so. Failure to separate services within the allotted time may
result in a fine up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). The
public works director or designee may extend the ninety-day deadline to
separate services at his or her discretion.
   B.   The Town may require by written agreement that any property or area to
be served by the water system of the Town be annexed into the Town prior to the
provision or installation of water services.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1D-2: ON-SITE WATER SYSTEM PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is unlawful to construct or maintain any private well within the
Town limits intended to be used as potable water.
   B.   Individual property owners may, at their own expense and upon approval
from the State Engineer and other licensing authority, install private wells
for irrigation purposes only.
   C.   Before commencement of construction of a private well for irrigation
purposes, the owner shall first obtain written permission from the governing
body. The request for such shall include any plans, specifications, and other
information as is deemed necessary by the governing body.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE E. USER CHARGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
13-1E-1: Generation Of Revenue
13-1E-2: Billing Status
13-1E-3: Improper Water Use
13-1E-4: Rates And Charges
13-1E-5: Vacant Units
13-1E-6: Monthly Billing Dates And Delinquent Accounts
13-1E-1: GENERATION OF REVENUE:
   The user charge system shall generate adequate annual revenues to pay costs
of annual operation and maintenance including replacement and other related
water system costs which the Town may determine by ordinance to be paid by the
user charge system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1E-2: BILLING STATUS:
   It is the responsibility of each property owner or tenant to notify the Town
of intent to change name, discontinue, begin or in any way alter billing
requirements. The application for service or for change of name or billing
shall be made upon the appropriate forms available at the Town Hall.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1E-3: IMPROPER WATER USE:
   Any person who shall knowingly take water from the Town's supply without
first having established an account shall pay the Town for the estimated water
used, plus pay the penalty of a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for such unlawful taking of water. Water shall be shut off from such
premises until such charges and/or penalties are paid.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1E-4: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   All metered structures shall be assessed a monthly water rate
consisting of a customer service charge, a demand charge and a commodity
charge.
   B.   The customer service charge shall be assessed to recover costs that
apply equally to each user of the system regardless of demand or quantity used.
It shall be billed on a customer account basis.
   C.   The demand charge shall be assessed to recover costs of debt service
and replacement fund for water facilities. It shall be based on the size of the
customer's meter or service and shall be established by resolution of the Town
Council.
   D.   The commodity charge shall be the amount charged a customer for the
quantity of water used during a billing period.
   E.   Charges shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
and shall be established by Resolution.
   F.   The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a
resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined
shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution.
The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the
budgetary process as is necessary to meet the anticipated expenditures of the
department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless
revised in any subsequent year.
   G.   A resolution shall be presented for governing body action to ratify
said adjustments. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges
during the budgetary process as is necessary to meet the anticipated
expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect
until or unless revised in any subsequent year.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1E-5: VACANT UNITS:
   Vacant units will not be charged for water service if the service is
discontinued by the Town and the Town has been properly informed in writing
that a unit is or will be vacant for a period of at least thirty (30) days.
After notification of discontinuance, the water at that residence shall be
turned off at the curb. The owner shall be assessed a fee as indicated in
Section
13-1E-4 E. If the property owner requests that the meter be pulled from a unit,
property owner shall be assessed a fee as indicated in Section
13-1E-4 E. Reconnect fees shall be as indicated in Section
13-1E-4 E.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1E-6: MONTHLY BILLING DATES AND DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS:
   A.   Property owner shall be responsible for payment of all utility bills
unless property owner assigns tenant responsibility for payment of such bills.
Such assignment shall be in writing. All utility bills shall be sent to the
property owner or tenant on a monthly basis. All monthly charges for water
shall be due and payable on the twentieth of each month. If payment is not made
by the twentieth of the month, the account shall be deemed delinquent and
account shall be subject to a five dollar ($5.00) rebilling charge. If payment
is not received within thirty (30) days after initial billing, a letter shall
be sent to the owner and tenant at the mailing address(es) on file. The letter
shall state:
      1.   That the account is delinquent;
      2.   That if the account is not paid in full on or before sixty (60) days
after the initial billing (giving the date of the sixtieth day), the account
shall be deemed in default and services discontinued; and
      3.   That the bill may be contested or challenged by contacting the Town
finance office (giving address and telephone number) prior to the fiftieth
(50th) day after initial billing (giving the date of the fiftieth day). If
payment of the account in full is not received or if the account is not settled
within sixty (60) days after initial billing, the account shall be deemed in
default and services discontinued.
   B.   Any residential, or commercial, property owner or tenant who has had
the water shutoff for nonpayment of utility charges shall pay the bill in its
entirety for all utility charges including water, sewer, garbage, landfill,
pest control, etc., and shall deposit with the Town a sum equivalent to two (2)
times the average monthly bill for all municipal utility services for that
property prior to service being restored.
   C.   For provisions concerning turn-on/turn-off fees, see Section
13-1E-4.
   D.   All deposits shall be held for a period of one (1) year. If the
property owner or tenant demonstrates good faith in payment of bills in a
timely fashion, the deposit shall be returned.
   E.   If the property owner or tenant cannot demonstrate good faith in
payment of the bill, the deposit shall be held by the Town until such time of
final billing. Final billing shall be made and deducted from moneys on deposit
and any balance returned to the property owner or tenant. The property owner or
tenant shall be responsible for payment of the final bill in total if the
deposit does not fully satisfy the debt to the Town.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE F. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
SECTION:
13-1F-1: Wardwell Water And Sewer District
13-1F-2: Regulations Promulgated By The Governing Body
13-1F-3: Access To Meters And Read-Out
13-1F-4: Liability For Negligence
13-1F-5: Restriction On Watering
13-1F-1: WARDWELL WATER AND SEWER DISTRICT:
   A.   At the time of the adoption of these Ordinances, the fees established
by the Wardwell Water and Sewer District are adopted by the Town of Bar Nunn,
unless otherwise set forth herein.
   B.   All provisions set forth herein for the administration of the water and
sewer system for the Town of Bar Nunn which are not specific to the municipal
authority of Bar Nunn, but which are applicable in its role as the
administrator of a water system that fall outside of its municipal boundaries
are adopted as policies and procedures of Bar Nunn in its capacity as the
administrator of the water system.
   C.   All policies and procedures adopted by the Wardwell Water & Sewer
District which are not contrary to provisions contained in Chapter 13 of the
Town Code of Bar Nunn, or are not specifically addressed by Chapter 13 of the
Town Code of Bar Nunn, are hereby adopted by reference.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1F-2: REGULATIONS PROMULGATED BY THE GOVERNING BODY:
   The governing body, at its discretion, may establish rules and regulations
for watering, distribution and operation of the water system as deemed fit and
necessary. This article, when implemented by the governing body, shall be
enforced by the Bar Nunn police department or Bar Nunn Code enforcement, when
with in the Town of Bar Nunn or by appropriate authorities when falling outside
of the municipal boundaries of the Town of Bar Nunn.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1F-3: ACCESS TO METERS AND READ-OUT:
   If a meter or remote read-out cannot be read because of locked gates, the
presence of a dog or any other obstacle preventing the meter reader or any
other agent of the Town from obtaining a reading, a written notice will be
given to the owner to remove such obstacle and make the meter or read-out
accessible.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1F-4: LIABILITY FOR NEGLIGENCE:
   If any person, other than authorized Town personnel, working on the Town's
water distribution system in any manner damages, destroys or causes the Town
system to be drained of water, that party shall be responsible and liable for
the loss of any water and such additional fee or costs as determined by the
Town shall be assessed accordingly.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-1F-5: RESTRICTION ON WATERING:
   A.   If in the opinion of the public works director and after discussions
and approval of the governing body that watering restrictions are deemed
necessary, such hours of restricted use shall be determined by the seriousness
of the water shortage. Public notice shall be given utilizing all reasonable
media.
   B.   Any violation of the hours for watering is declared to be unlawful and
such violation of any regulation shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($2500.00).
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
CHAPTER 2
SEWER SYSTEM
ARTICLE A. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND INFORMATION
SECTION:
13-2A-1: Duties Of Governing Body
13-2A-2: Powers And Duties Of Public Works Director
13-2A-3: Powers And Authority Of Public Works Director
13-2A-4: Interfering Or Tampering With Wastewater Treatment Facilities
13-2A-5: Falsifying Information
13-2A-1: DUTIES OF GOVERNING BODY:
   Subject to the laws relating to public utilities, the governing body shall
fix all rates for sewer charges, septic waste disposal facility charges,
connection fees and for services to users within the service area of the Town
and make regulations for the collection of the fees and charges.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR:
   The public works director, or his authorized representative and the town
clerk, shall enforce all necessary rules, regulations and penalties to enforce
the collection of fees or for the protection of the property and rights
pertaining to the town's wastewater system. This authority shall include the
power to make any administrative rules or regulations as may be necessary to
remain in compliance with EPA guidelines.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2A-3: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR:
   A.   The public works director and other duly authorized employees of the
town bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter
all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the community system in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and Chapter 2, Articles B
through G of this title.
   B.   The public works director or other duly authorized employees are
authorized to obtain information concerning industrial processes which have a
direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the wastewater collection
system. The industry may withhold information considered confidential. The
industry must establish that the revelation to the public of the information in
question might result in an advantage to a competitor.
   C.   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection A of this section, the public works director or duly authorized
employees of the town shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the company and the company shall be held harmless of injury or
death to the town employees and the town shall indemnify the company against
loss or damage to its property by town employees and against liability claims
and demands for personal injury for property damage asserted against the
company growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may
be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions
as required.
   D.   The public works director and other duly authorized employees bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the town holds a duly executed easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to inspection, observation, measurement, sampling,
repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within
the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement shall be
done in full accordance with the terms of the duly executed easement pertaining
to the private property involved.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2A-4: INTERFERING OR TAMPERING WITH WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES:
No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy,
uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which
is a part of the wastewater facility. Any person found guilty of violating this
provision shall be subject to a maximum fine of two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00), not including any civil liability which may be determined
for such damage. (Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2A-5: FALSIFYING INFORMATION:
Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or
certification in any application, record, report, plan, or other document
filed, or required to be maintained, pursuant to this division, or who
falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device
or method required under this division, shall, upon conviction, be subject to
the penalties as provided in Section 1-3-1 of the Bar Nunn Municipal Code.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE B. DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
13-2B-1: Generally
13-2B-1: GENERALLY:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used
in this division of this title shall be as set out in this chapter.
ACT OR THE ACT: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the
Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251, et seq.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD) OR BOD: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in
five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in milligrams per
liter.
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system
which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside
the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five
feet (5') (one and a half meters (1.5 m.)) outside the inner face of the
building wall.
BUILDING SEWER. The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal, also called "house connection," "lateral," or "service
line."
CERTIFIED ANALYTICAL REPORT: A report by a laboratory that is appropriately
certified by the Environmental Protection Agency or the Wyoming Department of
Environmental Quality.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer intended to receive both wastewater and storm or
surface water (not allowed in the town).
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
FLOATABLE OIL: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will
separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment
facility. Wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is
properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection
system.
GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Any waste listed as a hazardous waste in Subpart D, Section
261.30 of the Code of Federal Regulations.
HOLDING TANK WASTE: Any domestic sanitary waste from holding tanks such as
vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks and vacuum-pump tank
trucks.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The wastewater from industrial processes, trade or business
as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes.
INTERFERENCE: The inhibition or disruption of the wastewater treatment
processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of
the Town's NPDES permit.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer
overflows, into a watercourse, point, ditch, lake or other body of surface or
ground water.
NORMAL DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: Wastewater that has a BOD concentration of not more
than three hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l) and a suspended solids
concentration of not more than three hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l).
Normal domestic wastewater is considered to have a concentration which will
generally range from approximately one hundred twenty-five (125) to three
hundred milligrams per liter (300mg/l) of both BOD and suspended solids.
OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE: Expenditures during the useful life of the treatment
works for materials, labor, utilities and other items which are necessary for
managing and maintaining the sewage works to achieve the capacity and
performance for which such works were designed and constructed.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or
group.
pH: The reciprocal of the logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration. The
concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution.
Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven (7) and a hydrogen ion
concentration of 10-7 .
POLLUTANT: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage,
garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials,
radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar
dirt and industrial, municipal, and agricultural waste discharged into water.
POLLUTION: The man-made or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical,
biological and radiological integrity of water.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (0.5") (1.27 centimeters)
in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public
utility; a sewer main.
REPLACEMENT: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories
or appurtenances which are necessary in the useful life of the treatment works
to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and
constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement.
RESIDENTIAL CONTRIBUTOR: Any contributor to the town treatment works whose lot,
parcel of real estate or building is used for domestic dwelling purposes only.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from
residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together
with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface water that are not admitted
intentionally.
SEPTIC WASTE: Refers to trucked or hauled nonhazardous sanitary domestic waste,
as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Wyoming Department of
Environmental Quality.
SEPTIC WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY: That facility designated for the discharge of
domestic sanitary wastes into the Town's wastewater treatment facility.
SEWAGE: That spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater," as
defined below.
SEWER: A pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water.
SHALL/MAY: "Shall" is mandatory. "May" is permissive.
SLUDGE: Any solid, semi-solid or liquid waste generated from a municipal,
commercial or industrial wastewater treatment plant, water treatment plant, or
air pollution control facility exclusive of the treated effluent from a
wastewater treatment plant.
SLUG: Any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given
constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer
than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four (24)
hour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect
the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works.
STORM DRAIN–STORM SEWER: "Storm drain" (sometimes termed "storm sewer") means a
drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water or unpolluted
water from any source.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS (SS): "Suspended solids" or "SS" means total suspended matter
that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in water, wastewater
or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed
in "Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to
as nonfilterable residue.
TREATMENT WORKS: Any devices and systems for the storage, treatment, recycling
and reclamation of municipal sewage, domestic sewage or liquid industrial
waste. These include items, individual systems, pumping, power and other
equipment appurtenances; extensions, improvement, remodeling, additions and
alterations thereof; elements essential to provide a reliable recycling supply
such as standby treatment units and clear-well facilities; and any works
including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the
treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal of residue resulting from
such treatment; or any other method or system of preventing, abating, reducing,
storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal waste or industrial
waste, including waste and combined stormwater and sanitary sewer system.
UNPOLLUTED WATER: Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent
criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water
quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary
sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
USEFUL LIFE: The estimated period during which a treatment works will be
operating.
USER CHARGE: That portion of the total wastewater service charge which is
levied in a proportional and adequate manner for the cost of operation,
maintenance and replacement of the wastewater treatment works.
WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it
may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any
groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present.
WASTEWATER FACILITIES: The public structures, equipment and processes required
to collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of
the effluent.
WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. The term is sometimes used
as synonymous with "wastewater treatment plant" or "water pollution control
plant."
WATERCOURSE: A natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either
continuously or intermittently.
WATER METER: A water volume measuring and recording device furnished and/or
installed by the town.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE C. USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED
SECTION:
13-2C-1: Deposit Of Garbage In Unsanitary Manner Prohibited
13-2C-2: Discharge Of Untreated Wastewater Prohibited
13-2C-3: On-Site Disposal System Prohibited
13-2C-4: Septic Waste Disposal Facility
13-2C-5: Connection To Town Wastewater System Required-Annexation
13-2C-1: DEPOSIT OF GARBAGE IN UNSANITARY MANNER PROHIBITED:
   It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited
in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the town, or in
any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any human or animal excrement,
garbage or objectionable waste.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2C-2: DISCHARGE OF UNTREATED WASTEWATER PROHIBITED:
   It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the town, or in any
area under the jurisdiction of the town, any wastewater or other polluted
waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with
subsequent provisions of this article.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2C-3: ON-SITE DISPOSAL SYSTEM PROHIBITED:
   Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any
privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used
for the disposal of wastewater.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2C-4: SEPTIC WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY:
   Recreational vehicles and camper trailers may utilize designated septic
waste dumping stations within the Town limits to discharge sanitary waste
holding tank contents not exceeding one hundred (100) gallons.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2C-5: CONNECTION TO TOWN WASTEWATER SYSTEM REQUIRED–ANNEXATION:
   The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the town
and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located
or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the town, is
required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein
and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in
accordance with the provisions of this article within ninety (90) days after
date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within two
hundred feet (200') of the property line.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE D. PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL
SECTION:
13-2D-1: When Allowed
13-2D-2: Permission Required–Procedure
13-2D-3: Connection To Public Sewer Required When Available
13-2D-4: Responsibility For Maintenance Of Private System
13-2D-5: Additional Requirements Of Sanitarian
13-2D-1: WHEN ALLOWED:
   Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of
Section 13-2C-4, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater
disposal system complying with the provisions of Title 13, Chapter 2 of this
title.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2D-2: PERMISSION REQUIRED–PROCEDURE:
   A.   Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal
system, the owner(s) shall first obtain written permission from the governing
body. The request for such shall include any plans, specifications and other
information as are deemed necessary by the governing body. The approval of the
county sanitarian is also required. Permits for on-site wastewater disposal
shall be issued by sanitarian's office.
   B.   A permit for a private wastewater disposal system shall not become
effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the county
sanitarian. The sanitarian shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of
construction, and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the
sanitarian when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any
underground portions are covered.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2D-3: CONNECTION TO PUBLIC SEWER REQUIRED WHEN AVAILABLE:
   At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a
private wastewater disposal system, as defined in Chapter 2, Article A, a
direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within ninety (90) days in
compliance with Division II of this title, and any septic tanks, cesspools and
similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and
filled with sand.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2D-4: RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE OF PRIVATE SYSTEM:
   The owner(s) shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal
facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the town.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2D-5: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF SANITARIAN:
   No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with
any additional requirements that may be imposed by the county sanitarian or the
county board of health.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE E. BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS
SECTION:
13-2E-1: Permit Required For Work On Sewer System
13-2E-2: System Investment Fee Required
13-2E-3: Responsibility For Costs Of Installation
13-2E-4: Separate Sewer Service Line Required For Each Structure Or Dwelling
Unit
13-2E-5: Old Building Sewers In New Buildings
13-2E-6: Proper Design And Construction Of New Sewer And Connections
13-2E-7: Surface And Groundwater Drainage Connection Prohibited–Exception
13-2E-8: Safety Precautions During Excavation–Restoration Of Premises
13-2E-9: Responsibility For Maintenance
13-2E-1: PERMIT REQUIRED FOR WORK ON SEWER SYSTEM:
   No unauthorized person(s) shall uncover, make any connections with or
opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the Public Works. For excavation
in a Town right-of-way or other public land, a right-of-way permit shall be
obtained from the community development department. The permit shall cover such
items as: excavation, materials, backfill, compaction, replacement of asphalt
or concrete paving, replacement of curb, gutter and sidewalks and any other
materials required for complete restoration of the trenched area.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-2: SYSTEM INVESTMENT FEE REQUIRED:
   A.   There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits:
      Class A For residential and commercial service;
      Class B For service to establishments producing industrial wastes.
   B.   In either case, the owner(s) or his agent shall make application on a
special form furnished by the Town. The permit application shall be
supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered
pertinent in the judgment of the community development and public works
departments.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-3: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COSTS OF INSTALLATION:
   All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the
building sewer shall be borne by the property owner, developer or contractor.
201 Investment Fee shall be paid to the Town at the time of the issuance of the
tap permit. The owner(s) shall indemnify the Town from any loss or damage that
may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building
sewer. Fees shall be as indicated in Section
13-2G-4.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-4: SEPARATE SEWER SERVICE LINE REQUIRED FOR EACH STRUCTURE OR DWELLING
UNIT:
   A separate and independent sewer service line shall be provided for every
building, single family dwelling, multi-family dwelling, business structure or
mobile home park. Condominiums, townhouses and/or duplex units shall be
considered single-family units and shall have separate sewer service lines if
each unit is individually owned, or is capable of individual ownership.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-5: OLD BUILDING SEWERS IN NEW BUILDINGS:
   Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when
they are found, on examination of the Public Works Director, to meet all
requirements of this chapter and no new tap is made to a Town main.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-6: PROPER DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF NEW SEWER AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of all sanitary
sewers and sewer connections, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing
of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall conform to the
requirements of the building and plumbing code and other applicable rules and
regulations of the Town and the state.
   B.   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building
at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any
building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary
sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and
discharged to the building sewer.
   C.   The connections of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other
applicable rules and regulations of the Town. All such connections shall be
made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from
the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the community
development department before installation.
   D.   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the public
works department when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection
to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the
supervision of the public works department.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-7: SURFACE AND GROUNDWATER DRAINAGE CONNECTION PROHIBITED–EXCEPTION:
   No person(s) shall make connections of roof downspouts, foundations drains,
areaways drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a
building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or
indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the
public works department with concurrence from the Public works director.
Approval may be subject to conditions or restrictions as determined by public
works.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-8: SAFETY PRECAUTIONS DURING EXCAVATION–RESTORATION OF PREMISES:
   All excavations for building sewer\\ installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course
of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the town.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2E-9: RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE:
   All property owners connected to the town's wastewater treatment facility
shall keep and maintain the lateral line from the building connection to the
public sewer main, and shall keep the line in good repair at their own expense.
The town shall not be responsible for payment of any claim resulting from the
breakage of any line or for damage resulting from backup of sewer if the
breakage or backup occurs in the lateral line.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE F. USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS
SECTION:
13-2F-1: Discharge Of Unpolluted Waters Prohibited–Exception
13-2F-2: Specific Pollutant Limitations Designated
13-2F-3: Prohibited Materials Designated
13-2F-4: Powers Of Public Works Director Concerning Abuse
13-2F-5: Federal Categorical Pretreatment Standards
13-2F-6: State Requirements To Apply When
13-2F-7: Increasing Or Diluting To Avoid Proper Treatment Prohibited
13-2F-8: Grease, Oil And Sand Interceptors
13-2F-9: Pretreatment Or Flow Equalizing Facilities–Owner Responsibility
13-2F-10: Industrial Waste Monitoring Device
13-2F-11: Tests And Sampling Standards
13-2F-12: Special Arrangements For Industrial Users
13-2F-1: DISCHARGE OF UNPOLLUTED WATERS PROHIBITED--EXCEPTION:
   A.   No persons shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted
waters such as stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or
cooling water to any sewer, except stormwater runoff from limited areas, unless
such connection is approved by the public works department with concurrence
from the Public works director. Approval may be subject to conditions or
restrictions as determined by public works.
   B.   Stormwater, other than that exempted under subsection A of this
section, and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers
as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved
by the public works director and other regulatory agencies, or to a sanitary
sewer with the approval of public works and concurrence of the Public works
director as provided for in Section 13-2E-7. Unpolluted industrial cooling
water or process waters may be discharged, on approval of the public works
director, to a storm sewer or natural outlet.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-2: SPECIFIC POLLUTANT LIMITATIONS DESIGNATED:
   No person shall discharge any wastewater or other substance into the
wastewater treatment plant containing the following substances in excess of the
listed total concentration limitations:
 Limitation (mg/l) Discharges Greater Limitation (mg/l) Discharges Less Than 1%
