   Any other specific pollutants identified by the Town may also have specific
effluent permit limitations set by the Town to restrict their discharge into
the system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-3: PROHIBITED MATERIALS DESIGNATED:
   No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly,
any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operations or
performance of the wastewater treatment plant or septic waste disposal
facility. These general prohibitions apply to all such users of the wastewater
treatment facility whether or not the user is subject to National Categorical
Pretreatment Standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment
standards or requirements. A user may not contribute the following substances
to the wastewater treatment plant or septic waste disposal facility:
   A.   Any liquids, solids or gases which by reason of their nature or
quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other
substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the
wastewater treatment facility or to the operation of the wastewater treatment
facility, including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed cup flash-
point of less than one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit (140°F.) or sixty
degrees Celsius (60°C.) using test methods in 40 CFR 261.21, as enacted or
hereafter amended. At no time shall two (2) successive readings on an explosion
hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the
system) be more than five percent (5%), nor any single reading over ten percent
(10%) of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter. Prohibited materials
include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene,
xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates,
perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides, and any other
substances which the Town, the state, or EPA has notified the user is a fire
hazard or a hazard to the system;
   B.   Solid or viscous substances which may cause obstruction to the flow in
a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment
facilities such as, but not limited to: grease, garbage with particles greater
than one-half inch (0.5") in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch
manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers,
ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone, or marble dust, metal, glass, straw,
shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood,
plastics, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining, or processing of fuel
or lubricating oil, mud, or glass grinding or polishing wastes;
   C.   Petroleum-based oil in sufficient enough amounts that cause pass-
through or interference to the system, and in no cases exceeding one hundred
milligrams per liter (100 mg/l);
   D.   Any wastewater having a pH less than five (5.0) or greater than twelve
(12.0), or wastewater having any other corrosive property capable of causing
damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and/or personnel of the wastewater
treatment facility;
   E.   Any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity,
either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, to injure or interfere
with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or
animals, result in toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the wastewater treatment
facility in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems,
create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment
facility, or to exceed the limitation set forth in a categorical standard. A
toxic pollutant shall include but not be limited to any pollutant identified
pursuant to Section 307(a) of the Act;
   F.   Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, or solids which either singly
or by interaction with other wastes are sufficient to create a public nuisance
or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the public sewers for
maintenance and repair;
   G.   Any substance which may cause the wastewater treatment facility's
effluent or any other product of the wastewater treatment facility such as
residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to
interfere with the reclamation process. In no case shall a substance discharged
to the wastewater treatment facility cause the wastewater treatment facility to
be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or
regulations developed under Section 405 of the Act; any criteria, guidelines or
regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid
Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or
state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used;
   H.   Any substance which will cause the wastewater treatment facility to
violate its NPDES and/or State Disposal System Permit or the receiving water
quality standards;
   I.   Any wastewater with objectionable color which cannot be removed in the
treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable
tanning solutions;
   J.   Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological
activity in the wastewater treatment facility resulting in interference, but in
no case wastewater with a temperature above sixty-five degrees Celsius (65°C)
(one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or a temperature that causes the
wastewater treatment facility influent to exceed forty degrees Celsius (40°C)
(one hundred four degrees Fahrenheit (104°F);
   K.   Any pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.)
released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which a user knows or
has reason to know will cause interference to the wastewater treatment
facility. In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate or contain
concentration or quantities of pollutants that exceed limits set by the public
works director;
   L.   Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such
half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the
superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; and
   M.   Any wastewater which causes a hazard to human life or creates a public
nuisance.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-4: POWERS OF PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR CONCERNING ABUSE:
   A.   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged
to the public sewers, any of the substances listed in subsections (A) through
(M) of Section
13-2F-2 in such amounts as to have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater
facilities, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create
a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the public works director
may:
      1.   Reject the wastes; or
      2.   Advise the user of the impact of the contribution to the wastewater
treatment facility; and,
      3.   Develop effluent limitations for such user to correct the
interference with the wastewater treatment facility;
      4.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the
public sewers; and/or
      5.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
      6.   Require payment to cover added cost of handling and treating the
wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges.
   B.   If the public works director permits the pretreatment or equalization
of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall
be subject to the review and approval of the community development department.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-5: FEDERAL CATEGORICAL PRETREATMENT STANDARDS:
   Upon the promulgation of the categorical standard for a particular
industrial subcategory, the standard, if more stringent than limitations
imposed under this division for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately
supersede the limitations imposed under this division. The public works
director shall notify all affected users of the applicable reporting
requirements under 40 CFR 403.12, as enacted or hereafter amended.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-6: STATE REQUIREMENTS TO APPLY WHEN:
   State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case
where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or
those in this division.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-7: INCREASING OR DILUTING DISCHARGE TO AVOID PROPER TREATMENT PROHIBITED:
   No user shall increase the use of process water or, in any way, attempt to
dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment
to achieve compliance with the limitations contained in the categorical
standard, or in any other pollutant-specific limitation developed by the Town
or state.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-8: GREASE, OIL AND SAND INTERCEPTORS:
   Grease, oil, catchbasins and sand interceptors shall be provided or modified
when, in the opinion of the public works director, they are necessary for the
proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive
amounts, as specified in Section
13-2F-2(B), or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except
that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or
dwelling units. Modifications to existing interceptors may be required when
violations of this division exist. All interceptors shall be of a type and
capcity approved by the public works director and shall be located as to be
readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining
of these interceptors, the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal
and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain
records of the dates and means of disposal, which are subject to review by the
public works director. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not
performed by the owner's personnel must be performed by currently licensed
waste disposal firms.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-9: PRETREATMENT OR FLOW EQUALIZING FACILITIES–OWNER RESPONSIBILITY:
   Where pretreatment of flow equalizing facilities are provided or required
for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory
and effective operation by the owner(s) at his expense.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-10: INDUSTRIAL WASTE MONITORING DEVICE:
   When required by the Town, the owner of any property serviced by a building
sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable structure together
with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to
facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such structure,
when required, shall be accessible to Town personnel and safely located and
shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the community
development department. The structure shall be installed by the owner at his/
her expense and shall be maintained by him/her so as to be safe and accessible
at all times.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-11: TESTS AND SAMPLING STANDARDS:
   All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of waters and
wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of
Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association.
Sampling methods, location, times, duration and frequencies are to be
determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the public works
director.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2F-12: SPECIAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR INDUSTRIAL USERS:
   No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as preventing any
special agreement or arrangement between the Town and any industrial concern
whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by
the Town for treatment.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE G. USER CHARGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
13-2G-1: Purpose
13-2G-2: Generation Of Revenue
13-2G-3: Basis Of User Fee–Fee Structure
13-2G-4: Fee Structure For Users Not Served By Town Water System
13-2G-5: Surcharge For Excess BOD Or Suspended Solids
13-2G-6: Sewer Plant Investment Fees–Amount–Responsibility
13-2G-1: PURPOSE:
   It is determined and declared to be necessary and conducive to the
protection of the public health, safety and welfare to collect charges from all
users who contribute wastewater to the Town's treatment works. The proceeds of
such charges so derived will be used for the purpose of operation and
maintenance and other related costs as determined by the Town council for such
public wastewater treatment works.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2G-2: GENERATION OF REVENUE:
   The user charge system shall generate adequate annual revenues to pay costs
of annual operation and maintenance including replacement and other related
sewer system costs which the Town may determine by ordinance to be paid by the
user charge system. That portion of the total user charge which is designated
for operation and maintenance including replacement of the treatment works
shall be established by ordinance.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2G-3: BASIS OF USER FEE-FEE STRUCTURE:
   All users within the Town's service area shall be assessed a monthly sewer
user rate consisting of a customer service charge and a volume charge.
   A.   The customer service charge shall be assessed to recover costs that
apply equally to each user of the system regardless of volume contribution. It
shall be billed on a customer account basis.
   B.   The volume charge shall be the amount charged a customer for the
quantity of wastewater contributed to the Town's system during a billing
period.
      1.   For the single-family residential and multifamily residential users,
this fee shall be based on the average water used by that user during the
winter quarter (December, January and February) as measured at the dwelling by
the Town water meter. A single-family residential and multifamily residential
user may submit a written request to the Public works director or designated
representative to use alternate months for the averaging period. The Public
works director or designated representative is authorized to substitute
different month of a calendar year to obtain a three (3) month averaging period
to calculate the annual sewer average for the user and adjust the sewer user
fee accordingly. The following situations may be considered by the Public works
director or designated representative to select an alternate month to be used
for the recalculation of the sewer user fee: weather conditions, shut-off of
service, new ownership, irrigation, or leaks within the user's dwelling. The
Public works director or designated representative may utilize the prior year's
average when a three (3) month averaging period cannot be determined due to the
situations noted herein.
      2.   For single-family residential users not having a winter water
consumption history, their sewer bill for the first month of service and every
month thereafter shall be based on the number of reported occupants times two
thousand (2,000) gallons per occupant per month with a minimum implied water
usage of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month. After a period of three (3)
full months as measured at the dwelling by the Town water meter, a single-
family residential user may submit a written request to the Public works
director or designated representative for a review of the average sewer
consumption used by the user. The Public works director or designated
representative will calculate the annual sewer average based on this period of
three (3) full months and adjust the sewer user fee accordingly. For
multifamily residential users not having a winter water consumption history,
the sewer average shall be based on the previous owner's average. When a
previous owner's average is not available due to new construction or shut off
of services the sewer average shall be based on the number of reported
occupants for all units times two thousand (2,000) gallons per occupant with a
minimum implied water usage of two thousand (2,000) gallons per unit per month.
Otherwise, the assigned average monthly water consumption will be used until
such time as a winter quarter water consumption history is obtained for the
individual user.
      3.   For residential users who purchase and move to another property
within the Town, the established volume charge will be transferred to the new
property.
   C.   Charges shall made by the Governing Body of the Town of Bar Nunn by
resolution. The rates and charges established in this section may be modified
by a resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so
determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent
resolution. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges
during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated
expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect
until or unless revised in any subsequent year.
   D.   A resolution shall be presented for governing body action to ratify
said adjustments. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges
during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated
expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect
until or unless revised in any subsequent year.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2G-4: FEE STRUCTURE FOR USERS NOT SERVED BY TOWN WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   Any commercial user served by the wastewater system of the Town who is
not served by the water system of the Town shall install a Town-approved water
meter on the user's private well(s).
      1.   This meter shall be installed prior to connection to Town wastewater
system except as provided in subsection B of this section. The owner of the
property upon which an approved water meter is located shall assure that such
meter is at all times in good working order, and shall contact the public works
director to cause the meter to be repaired or replaced. The property owner
shall bear all costs of meter installation and repair or replacement. For
additional provisions concerning water meter installation and property owner
responsibilities, see Title 13, Chapter 1.
      2.   Such meter shall be read on a monthly basis to determine volume
charge for the purpose of billing for wastewater contribution to the Town's
system. The fee structure shall be in accordance with Section 13-2G-3 of this
code.
   B.   Any residential user served by the wastewater system of the Town who is
not served by the water system of the Town shall be charged a monthly volume
charge based upon the Town-wide average residential water consumption of the
winter quarter. This volume rate will be adjusted annually in conjunction with
the annual sewer rate calculation for residential users served by the Town
water system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2G-5: SURCHARGE FOR EXCESS BOD OR SUSPENDED SOLIDS:
   A.   For those contributors who contribute wastewater, the strength of which
is greater than the upper limit of normal domestic sewage, a surcharge in
addition to the normal charge will be collected. This surcharge shall be
determined by the town based on estimates of treatment costs of excess BOD and
SS concentrations at the time such contributors are connected to the town's
wastewater treatment system.
   B.   Any user which discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase
in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge from the town's treatment
works, or any user which discharges any substance which singly or by
interaction with other substances causes identifiable increases in the cost of
operation, maintenance or replacement of the treatment works, shall pay for
such increased costs. The strength of effluent shall be determined by the
responsible plant operating personnel and users shall be charged the additional
surcharge rates as provided by ordinance.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2G-6: SEWER PLANT INVESTMENT FEES-AMOUNT-RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   All charges for connection to the Town's wastewater system made
pursuant hereto shall be paid by the owner of the property, developer or
contractor and shall be paid to the Town upon issuance of the tap permit. A
right-of-way permit will be required for excavation onto Town right-of-way or
other public land. Charges shall be set by the Governing Body of the Town of
Bar Nunn.
   B.   For any sanitary sewer connection over four inches (4"), the wastewater
plant investment fee shall be negotiated by the Public works director according
to existing conditions at the time of the request for such connection.
   C.   Any property served by the Town outside the corporate limits shall be
charged one and one-half (1.5) times the total plant investment fees indicated
in this section unless otherwise set forth in Chapter 13 or subject to any
separate Agreements or Memoranda of Understanding at the time of the adoption
of Chapter 13.
   D.   The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a
resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined
shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution.
The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the
budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures
of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or
unless revised in any subsequent year.
   E.   A resolution shall be presented for governing body action to ratify
said adjustments. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges
during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated
expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect
until or unless revised in any subsequent year.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE H. BILLING–CALL-OUT FEES–RIGHT TO DISCONTINUE SERVICE
SECTION:
13-2H-1: Billing Status
13-2H-2: Vacant Units
13-2H-3: Monthly Billing Dates And Delinquent Account
13-2H-4: Improper Wastewater Use
13-2H-5: Utility Call-Out Fees
13-2H-1: BILLING STATUS:
   It is the responsibility of each property owner or tenant to notify the Town
of intent to change name, discontinue, begin or in any way alter billing
requirements. The application for service or for change of name or billing
shall be made upon the appropriate forms available at Town Hall. Nothing shall
be deemed to relieve a property owner from ultimate responsibility for any
chargers pertaining to services supplied to his or her real property,
regardless of a property owners assigning those duties to a tenant or other
third party.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2H-2: VACANT UNITS:
   Vacant units will not be charged for sewer service if the water service is
discontinued by the Town and the Town has been properly informed in writing
that a unit is or will be vacant for a period of at least thirty (30) days.
After notification of discontinuance, the water at the residence shall be shut
off at the curb.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2H-3: MONTHLY BILLING DATES AND DELINQUENT ACCOUNT:
   A.   Property owner shall be responsible for payment of all utility bills
unless property owner assigns tenant responsibility for payment of such bills.
Such assignment shall be in writing. All utility bills shall be sent to the
property owner or tenant on a monthly basis. All monthly charges for wastewater
services shall be due and payable on the twentieth of each month. If payment is
not made by the twentieth of the month, the account shall be deemed delinquent.
If payment is not received within thirty (30) days after initial billing, a
letter shall be sent to the owner and tenant at the mailing address(es) on
file. The letter shall state:
      1.   That the account is delinquent;
      2.   That if the account is not paid in full on or before sixty (60) days
after the initial billing (giving the date of the sixtieth day), the account
shall be deemed in default and services discontinued; and
      3.   That the bill may be contested or challenged by contacting the Town
finance office (giving address and telephone number) prior to the fiftieth day
after initial billing (giving the date of the fiftieth day). If payment of the
account in full is not received or if the account is not settled within sixty
(60) days after initial billing, the account shall be deemed in default and
services discontinued.
   B.   Any residential, or commercial, property owner or tenant who has had
service discontinued for nonpayment of utility charges shall pay the bill in
its entirety for all utility charges including water, sewer, garbage, landfill,
pest control, etc., and shall deposit with the Town a sum equivalent to two (2)
times the average monthly bill for all municipal utility services for that
property prior to service being restored.
   C.   Users served by the Town water system shall have water shutoff for
nonpayment of utility charges. At the time of turn-on of service, the property
owner shall be assessed the applicable fees and deposit as specified in
Sections
13-1E-4 and 13-1E-7.
   D.   Users not served by the Town water system shall be subject to
discontinuance of service by capping of their wastewater service line by the
utility department. Such discontinuance shall require the express authorization
of the Public works director prior to capping. If services are restored during
regular working hours of utility department staff, the turn-on fee shall be one
hundred dollars ($100.00) if wastewater service has been capped. If services
are restored during other than regular working hours, the turn-on fee shall be
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) if wastewater service has been capped. At
the time of turn-on of service, the property owner shall be assessed the
deposit as specified in Section 13-1E-7.
   E.   The deposit shall be held for a period of one (1) year. If the property
owner or tenant demonstrates good faith in payment of bills in a timely
fashion, the deposit shall be returned.
   F.   If the property owner or tenant cannot demonstrate good faith in
payment of bills, the deposit shall be held by the Town until such time of
final billing. Final billing shall be made and deducted from moneys on deposit
and any balance returned to the property owner or tenant. The property owner or
tenant shall be responsible for the payment of the final bill in total if the
deposit does not fully satisfy the debt to the Town.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2H-4: IMPROPER WASTEWATER USE:
   A.   Any person who discharges wastewater into the Town's wastewater system
without first having established an account shall pay the Town a flat monthly
rate based on the average monthly volume contributed for that customer class
for the number of months person has so discharged. In addition, it shall be
unlawful for any person to knowingly discharge wastewater into the Town's
wastewater system without first having established an account. A violation of
this subsection shall result in a fine not to exceed two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00) for such unlawful usage of Town wastewater system.
   B.   The Public works director shall be authorized to direct that sewer
service line serving such premises is capped until any past charges, fees and/
or penalties are paid.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-2H-5: UTILITY CALL-OUT FEES:
   The Town shall assess a call-out fee for emergency service rendered after
hours, on weekends or holidays. The amount of the call-out fee shall be
established by resolution of the Town council and shall take into account the
cost of prevailing wages for utility department employees together with the
appropriate benefit calculation. Billing to person requesting said call-out
shall be made by finance department upon receipt of billing information from
public utility department. Such fees shall be reviewed and revised as necessary
on an annual basis. Failure to conduct the annual review shall be grounds for
the initiation of a current review process only and shall not invalidate
existing fee schedules which shall remain in effect until modified by
affirmative council action.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
CHAPTER 3
SANITATION COLLECTION
ARTICLE A. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND INFORMATION
SECTION:
13-3A-1: Duties Of Governing Body
13-3A-2: Powers And Duties Of Public Works Director
13-3A-3: Responsibilities Of Public Works Department Director
13-3A-4: Definitions
13-3A-5: Collection-Intervals
13-3A-6: Damaging Solid Waste Containers
13-3A-1: DUTIES OF GOVERNING BODY:
   Subject to the laws relating to public utilities, the governing body may fix
all rates for sanitation and solid waste collection services within the
corporate limits of the Town and make regulations for the collection of the
fees and charges where applicable.
   Nothing shall preclude the Town from contracting for the collection of solid
wastes in which case the terms and conditions of such a contract shall govern
all such matters while the contract is in effect.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR:
   The Public works director, or his/her authorized representative, shall
enforce all necessary rules, regulations and penalties to enforce the
collection of fees and for the protection of the Town's property and rights
pertaining to the Town's sanitation collection and solid waste disposal system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3A-3: RESPONSIBILITIES OF PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT DIRECTOR:
The public works director shall be responsible for the management and direction
of the Town's sanitation and solid waste collection and disposal system.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3A-4: DEFINITIONS:
CONSTRUCTION/ DEMOLITION WASTE: Includes but is not limited to stone, wood,
concrete, asphaltic concrete, cinder blocks, plaster and metal.
DEBRIS: Discarded automobile parts, household appliances, furniture,
construction materials, dead animals, or any other materials too large to be
disposed of in a standard solid waste container, or which may be inappropriate
for deposit in a regular solid waste disposal pit.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Any waste or combination of wastes which pose a substantial
present or potential hazard to human health or the environment, as defined as
hazardous wastes in Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality Hazardous Waste
Rules and Regulations, Chapter 2, Identification and Listing of Hazardous
Waste.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS: Paper products, aluminum, glass, plastics, metal cans, or
newspapers which can be diverted from the waste stream.
SCAVENGING: The unauthorized removal of solid waste or debris from the landfill
site after it has been collected and deposited in accordance with Division III
of this title.
SOLID WASTE: Any and all kitchen refuse, waste food, offal or animal matter, or
anything else whatsoever which may decompose and become offensive, unsanitary
or dangerous to health; or any other refuse such as paper products, cans,
bottles, or other waste materials which may be safely and conveniently disposed
of in a standard solid waste container.
YARD WASTE: Leaves or grass clippings suitable for composting.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3A-5: COLLECTION–INTERVALS:
   All solid waste shall be collected and disposed of at regular intervals as
prescribed in Section 13-3B-6, Collection of solid waste is subject to
restrictions as per Section
13-3B-5.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3A-6: DAMAGING SOLID WASTE CONTAINERS:
   No person shall in any manner tamper with, deface or destroy any solid waste
container belonging to the Town. Any person found guilty of these acts shall be
subject to a maximum fine of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2500.00) for
each such container damaged.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE B. CONTAINERS–COLLECTION
SECTION:
13-3B-1: Containers Required–Specifications
13-3B-2: Reserved
13-3B-3: Responsibility Of Owner To Maintain Container
13-3B-4: Use Of Containers–Collection Generally
13-3B-5: Placement Of Containers
13-3B-6: Frequency Of Collection
13-3B-1: CONTAINERS REQUIRED-SPECIFICATIONS:
   Every owner or occupant of any occupied premises within the Town shall
obtain and utilize solid waste containers provided by the Town or the Town's
contractor.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3B-2: RESERVED:  
[Reserved by Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024.]
13-3B-3: RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER TO MAINTAIN CONTAINER:
   It shall be the duty of every user of the Town's sanitation collection
system to maintain the container or dumpster in good order.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3B-4: USE OF CONTAINERS–COLLECTION GENERALLY:
   A.   It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of any premises within
the Town limits to deposit in the appropriate container all solid waste
produced at or brought into any such premise.
   B.   All solid waste must be in paper or plastic bags, tied securely, and
placed in the container. No container shall be allowed to overflow so that
solid waste may be blown or scattered about in any way.
   C.   No debris or excessively heavy yard waste shall be placed in any
dumpster or roll-out container, as such materials can damage container and/or
mechanical parts of the sanitation truck.
   D.   Users of the Town's sanitation system are required to separate yard
waste and are encouraged to separate recyclable materials out of the solid
waste deposited into Town containers and place same in receptacles specifically
designed for such use.
   E.   No person shall deposit any solid waste or other debris in another's
solid waste container unless the consent of the property owner or occupant of
the premises is first obtained. Yard waste shall not be permitted in any
containers other than those designated for such use. Solid waste containers
located on public property are designed for visitors and specific users of such
public property and are not designed for the regular deposit of solid waste by
non-Town residents.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3B-5: PLACEMENT OF CONTAINERS:
   A.   Dumpsters shall be located in alleys at positions determined by the
public works department to facilitate ease of route flow.
   B.   Dumpsters on commercial property parking lots shall be placed in a
three (3) sided enclosure to screen the dumpster from public view. Plans for
the enclosure shall be approved by the public works director and are the
responsibility of the developer to install and maintain to Town specifications.
   C.   Roll-out containers shall be placed in the gutter in front of the
residence by seven (7:00) a.m. on the designated collection day. No person
shall place the roll-out in the street prior to one (1) calendar day before the
collection of the solid waste, nor shall any person leave the roll-out in the
street more than twenty-four (24) hours after collection.
   D.   No vehicle shall be parked so as to obstruct access by sanitation
collection crews to any dumpster or roll-out.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3B-6: FREQUENCY OF COLLECTION:
   A.   Residential. The collection of solid waste in residential areas shall
be made once a week according to route schedules determined by the public works
director.
   B.   Commercial. The collection of solid waste for commercial properties
shall be made daily or at other reasonable intervals as requested.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE C. RESERVED
   [Reserved by Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024.]
ARTICLE D. USER CHARGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
13-3D-1: Generation Of Revenue
13-3D-2: Billing Status
13-3D-3: Rates And Charges–Sanitation Collection And Solid Waste Disposal
13-3D-4: Vacant Units
13-3D-5: Monthly Billing Dates And Delinquent Accounts
13-3D-1: GENERATION OF REVENUE:
   The user charge system shall generate adequate revenues to pay all costs of
operation and maintenance, as determined by generally accepted accounting
principles, including equipment replacement and capital improvements.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3D-2: BILLING STATUS:
   It is the responsibility of each property owner or tenant to notify the Town
of intent to change name, discontinue, begin or in any way alter billing
requirements. Application forms to obtain, modify or discontinue a service
account shall be available at Town Hall. Nothing shall relieve a property
owners of responsibility for chargers for services to the property owner's real
property, including assignment of the same to a third party.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3D-3: RATES AND CHARGES–SANITATION COLLECTION AND SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL:
   A.   All users of the Town's sanitation collection and solid waste disposal
system shall be assessed a monthly rate on a customer account set by the
Governing Body of Bar Nunn by Resolution.
   B.   The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a
resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined
shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution.
The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the
budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures
of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or
unless revised in any subsequent year.
   C.   The Town may establish special handling fees at the solid waste
facility to cover special circumstances such as large construction or
demolition loads, tires, dead animals or hazardous materials that impact the
daily operation method and operational life of the facility. Such disposal
shall be allowed according to the conditions of the operating regulations of
the facility. Fee structures for such special charges shall be established from
time to time by resolution.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3D-4: VACANT UNITS:
   Vacant units will not be charged for sanitation collection or solid waste
disposal service if the water service is discontinued by the Town and the unit
is or will be vacant for a period of at least thirty (30) days and the Town has
been informed in writing that such unit is vacant. After notification of
discontinuance, the water at the residence shall be shut off at the curb and
the solid waste collection receptacle removed, if applicable.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3D-5: MONTHLY BILLING DATES AND DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS:
   All utility bills shall be sent to the property owner or tenant on a monthly
basis. All monthly charges for solid waste shall be due and payable on the
twentieth of each month. If payment is not made by the twentieth of the month,
the account shall be deemed delinquent. If payment is not received within sixty
(60) days after initial billing, the account shall be deemed in default.
Accounts in default shall be subject to the provisions of Section 13-1E-6.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE E. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
SECTION:
13-3E-1: Regulations Promulgated By Governing Body–Enforcement
13-3E-2: Penalties
13-3E-1: REGULATIONS PROMULGATED BY GOVERNING BODY–ENFORCEMENT:
   The governing body at its discretion may establish additional rules and
regulations for sanitation collection, solid waste disposal and hours of
operation for the landfill. Division III of this title shall be enforced by the
police department under the direction of the Public works director.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
13-3E-2: PENALTIES:
   Any person guilty of violating any provision of this division shall be
subject to a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
such offense.
(Ord. 2024-01, 5-7-2024)
